PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke) took the chair at 2.30 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COLEMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 187 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
A substantial contribution to Australia's economy by the payment of taxation and to the quality of life of fellow Australians, is made by parents in the work-force who have pre-school children.
Taxation relief for adequate child-care is necessary to enable these parents to avail themselves of child-care facilities in order to take paid employment.

Your petitioners therefore humble pray that taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Patients' Medical Records
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are gravely concerned by the invasion of privacy caused by Government agents seizing patient medical records.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Legislate to protect the private and confidential nature of medical records from scrutiny except on the express and informed consent of the patient or an order from a presiding judge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Women's Advisory Council
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the National Women's Advisory Council has not been democratically elected by the women of Australia;
That the National Women's Advisory Council is not representative of the women of Australia;
That the National Women's Advisory Council is a discriminatory and sexist imposition on Australian Women as Australian men do not have a National Men's Advisory Council imposed on them.

That the National Women's Advisory Council be abolished to ensure that Australian women have equal opportunity with Australian men of having issues of concern to them considered, debated and voted on by their Parliamentary representatives without intervention and interference by an unrepresentative 'Advisory Council'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-All Australians heard with deep shock and concern this morning the news of an attempt on the life of President Reagan. President Reagan has undergone surgery and his condition is reported to be good. His Press Secretary, Mr James Brady, who was also shot, is reported as being in a critical condition. One security guard and one policeman were also shot. A young assailant has been charged with these shootings.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the latest tragic example of the vulnerability of public figures in the United States to the threat of attempted assassination and part of an increasing pattern of political violence around the world which continues to shock all decent people. The news that we have of the President's condition gives us some relief. We have all heard the reports of his bravery and good spirits in the aftermath of this attempt on his life. We salute and admire him for it. We all hope and pray for his speedy and complete recovery.

At this time of trial, the United States Government and people are demonstrating yet again their great strength and resilience as a nation. The United States people should know that we in Australia respond to this shocking event in a spirit of complete sympathy, support and concern for all those people personally involved and their families. I inform the Senate that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) this morning sent personal messages to Mrs Reagan, to the President and to Secretary of State Haig, expressing our sincere concern and our hopes for a speedy recovery for all those involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I indicate very briefly that the Opposition shares the concern expressed by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) at the attempt on the life of President Reagan. We also take the opportunity of wishing him a speedy recovery to good health and of expressing our sympathy to the relatives of those involved in the shooting incident who, as it emerges, suffered much more serious injuries than the President himself. We otherwise share the sentiments expressed in the ministerial statement.

—by leave-The Australian Democrats are also appalled at this latest outbreak of violence against a head of state. We extend our sympathies to President Reagan, Mr James Brady, the security guard and the policeman who were also shot. We record the hope that both those who approve of aggression as a means of settling disputes and those who advocate violence in solving disagreements of any kind will soon see the total futility of such action. We also hope that out of this further tragedy the world may yet learn something about the hopelessness of bloodshed.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Senator Durack, whether he has seen reports that the Executive Director of the Australian Institute of Sport, Mr Don Talbot, has expressed serious doubts about the Institute's future and will be considering his own position at the end of the year. Does Mr Talbot allege that the Government has broken its promises about the provision of sporting facilities? Are there also complaints about a shortage of money for transport of those athletes on scholarships and about the state of the oval at Bruce Stadium in Canberra? In view of the political mileage which the Government sought to achieve from the establishment of the Australian Institute of Sport following the Olympic Games boycott efforts, what action, if any, does the Government propose to take to rectify the situation described by Mr Talbot?
—I think this is a matter which falls within the portfolio of my colleague the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment.
—This document says 'Senator Durack', but it is probably out of date.

—If it is a question relating to home affairs, I think it concerns Mr Wilson. The question is one of detail in a large number of parts. I am not aware of the particular matters raised by Mr Talbot. I will undertake to refer this matter to my colleague and to come back with an answer as quickly as I can.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer to a recent article in the Adelaide Press which suggested that South Australia faces major cuts in tax sharing revenue. In view also of the recent remarks of the Minister for Industry and Commerce at a meeting of the New South Wales Liberal Council that the States would have to reduce their spending, can the Minister indicate whether the Commonwealth does intend to make major cuts in the amount of tax sharing revenue which South Australia receives? Can the Minister further indicate whether the reasons for these cuts are the reported fact that South Australia does not have an expensive country rail network overhead and the income South Australia is receiving from natural gas sales?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been some newspaper reports on this matter and they were drawn to the Treasurer's attention. The States (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976 is presently being reviewed by the Commonwealth and the States. The States have indicated to the Commonwealth that they would not wish the existing tax sharing arrangement to continue unaltered. The Commonwealth Government is presently considering the views of the States with a view to determining its own attitude to the future tax sharing arrangements with the States.

ANSWER.PARA: This matter is to be discussed at a Premiers Conference on 15 April. In advance of that conference it would not be appropriate for me to make any comment on this matter other than to indicate that it is the Government's general objective to reduce the size of the public sector and to make room for the very considerable opportunities for expansion of the private sector which have developed as a result of the Government's economic policies. Within the context of whatever new tax sharing arrangements are determined, the Government will be considering the share of the total entitlement to be paid to South Australia in the light of the inquiry of the Commonwealth Grants Commission into relativities between the States. The Grants Commission is required to report before 30 June this year and, as the report will not be available until later in the financial year, the question of States' shares will not be determined at the Premiers Conference to be held on 15 April.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware that over 40 projects concerning accommodation for the aged in Victoria for which funds were promised before the last election are in jeopardy because the Commonwealth and Victorian governments are in conflict over eligibility requirements, since the Victorian legislation now requires hospital boards to be government-appointed? Will the Minister introduce legislation to include these hospitals and associated nursing homes among organisations eligible for funding under the Act, or will the approvals continue to be held up, thereby increasing costs and anxieties in the communities where nursing homes are needed?

—It has not been brought to my attention that there is a delay of the sort which the honourable senator has indicated, but his sources of information are usually impeccable. I certainly will make inquiries about the matter. It is not the wish of the Commonwealth to see projects delayed because of problems between the Commonwealth and the State. I certainly will let him have a reply as soon as possible as to the accurate position and what can be done to alleviate any concern there may be about the matter in Victoria.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services aware of criticisms of the low standard of paper used by government departments, in particular its acidic content which is causing the early deterioration of government records and which in future will seriously restrict the preservation and retention of archival material? Will the Minister investigate this situation and see whether higher standards can be required of paper manufacturers and suppliers to overcome this problem?

—I am certain that my colleague, the Minister for Administrative Services, would want to follow up the matter raised by Senator Missen. It might be helpful as a first step to make certain that we have all the information that is available to the honourable senator on the criticisms of the paper and its pH qualities that he wants to have improved. I will undertake to refer that matter to my colleague. I think all honourable senators would like to make sure that the archival functions of the Commonwealth can be carried out to the very best standards.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Has a major new crisis erupted in the last few days in the funding of legal aid in Victoria? Is there a shortfall of approximately $1m in the funds required for the Australian Legal Aid Office to be able to grant aid at the normal rate between now and the end of this financial year? I ask the Attorney-General whether he will confirm that the following steps, among others, have so far been taken to meet the crisis: The axing of the position of Family Court duty solicitor, a substantial increase in the contributions required for those granted aid, a redefinition of the notion of merit to exclude numerous applications which would otherwise be within the guidelines, the outright rejection of at least 15 per cent of applicants who would otherwise be within the guidelines, a deliberate delay in the processing of applications and, most importantly and alarmingly of all, the implementation of a deliberate policy of deception in the Melbourne office in which senior officers have apparently directed junior officers to tell lies in response to inquiries-namely, in the case of those to whom legal aid is likely to be granted, that the delay is simply the product of a typing crisis; and in the case of those who are not likely to get aid, that their applications are under sympathetic consideration. Finally, I ask: Does the Minister accept responsibility for the maladministration apparently lying behind this new crisis? Does he approve of the administrative steps which have been taken so far and which I have outlined? Will the Government provide the funds that are necessary to overcome the crisis?

—In the previous Budget there was a very substantial increase in the provision of funds for legal aid. In fact, I think the increase was somewhat in excess of the rate of inflation, as it has been for many years. Administering these funds is always very difficult. As I have said over and over again, the funds are always stretched because of the demands upon them. Therefore, from time to time in the course of administration situations can develop which require some corrective measures. I am unaware of the particular matters Senator Evans has raised. I will certainly investigate them. I hope I will be in a better position to provide a detailed answer in the next day or two, after I have had the opportunity of doing that.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to allegations by the Director of the Bangkok office of the International Red Cross, Francois Perez, that doctors along the Thai-Kampuchean border had treated 65 people with poisoning symptoms between 7 March and 15 March. Repeated allegations have been made over a considerable period that Vietnamese forces are using chemicals and poison gas in Kampuchea and Laos, and in Laos particularly against the Hmong people. In evidence given to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence a representative of the Hmong people detailed these allegations several weeks ago. Having in mind the fact that last year the United Nations General Assembly adopted a resolution calling for an investigation of the use of chemical warfare in many parts of the world, which resolution was predictably opposed by the Soviet Union, Vietnam and Laos, will the Government again raise this matter in the United Nations and press for a thorough investigation of these repeated allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer the matter raised by Senator Sim to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and seek an early response from him.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, follows a question asked in this place on 25 March by Senator Kilgariff concerning the proposed makarrata or treaty of commitment with Aboriginal people. The Minister, in his reply to Senator Kilgariff, enumerated those proposals from the National Aboriginal Conference which the Government has rejected out of hand. Today I ask the Minister: What financial and legal issues will the Government be prepared to negotiate on for a makarrata? What steps is the Government taking to negotiate with State governments on these issues? Will the Government announce a timetable for the completion of negotiations concerning a makarrata?

—The matter of negotiations with the States has only recently been opened up at the ministerial Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council meeting in Darwin. The only agreement we have at the moment is the agreement of several of the States to negotiate with the National Aboriginal Conference. The matter is clearly at a very early stage at this moment. I think it will take some time before the States and the NAC are in a position to have any kind of agreed position, and it would not be appropriate at this stage to indicate a proposed date for the makarrata to be finalised. From our point of view, we are keen to investigate with the NAC a number of areas which we can examine together. All that has happened is that we have responded to the first proposals by the NAC by rejecting some of the matters which we felt were not a basis for negotiation. The Government has been prepared to acknowledge a whole range of matters. It has been prepared to acknowledge prior occupation. It has been prepared to acknowledge dispossession and disadvantage, as it has done in legislation which has come into this place. In fact, I have suggested to the NAC that it may wish to put a series of proposals to the Government about outcome objectives which we might aim for in a whole range of Aboriginal advancement programs. The Conference has yet to come back to me on this and other matters, but we are looking to an active participation in developing another proposal for government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to an article which appeared in yesterday's edition of the Courier-Mail wherein it was reported that two Aborigines have died and a number of others have been admitted to the hospital in Alice Springs as a result of what now appears to have been strychnine poisoning. I seek the Minister's assurance that he will use the authority of his office to ensure that a full and complete investigation is made of this incident to ascertain the person or persons responsible and that such person or persons are brought to justice. I further draw the Minister's attention to the closing paragraphs of the article and ask him to demonstrate officially his abhorrence of the callous and discriminatory manner in which the author fails to make any distinction between the death of dogs and the death of my people. Mr President, I crave your indulgence to read from the article to demonstrate why I find it so offensive to me and to other Aborigines. The article is headed 'Poison possible deaths cause' and commences with a report concerning the number of people involved and so on. It then states that police did not know what was the cause at the time. The offending part reads:

QUESTION.PARA: Alice Springs has a history of active dog baiters and one resident said that they had been active for more than 30 years.
On one estimate, more than 1,500 dogs have been killed since 1947. According to a resident the baiters' favourite poison was strychnine.
. . . one veterinarian last weekend successfully treated 10 dogs for poisoning. He lost another four and two further deaths were reported . . .
I find offensive the manner in which the article was put together.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been confirmed that an Aboriginal male and female are dead and that six other Aborigines have been admitted to hospital as a result of strychnine poisoning on 29 March. It is believed that the poison was contained in a bottle of wine which was consumed by the group. Samples from the hospital patients and from the deceased have confirmed the presence of strychnine. The group involved was composed of Aboriginals from Papunya, Indulkana and Hermannsburg. The honourable senator asked whether I will use the authority of my office to investigate the matter. The event occurred within the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory police are actively involved. The police investigations are now being carried out under Detective Chief Inspector Pope. They are continuing. Like Senator Bonner, I hope that the investigations will very quickly reveal the cause of the deaths and that if people were responsible they will be apprehended.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not seen the Courier-Mail article to which the honourable senator referred; and I have not seen the last paragraphs which he has just read out. It is a matter of tragedy that anyone should have been poisoned as this group of Aboriginals were. I think all honourable senators would agree with that statement. I hope that it was not the intention of the Courier-Mail to offend Aboriginal people. If that is what has occurred, I am sure the newspaper will be appropriately apologetic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that Mr Robert Holmes a'Court made a tax free profit of about $16m during his recent share market raid on the Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort company? Did Mr Holmes a'Court avoid capital gains tax on this transaction by the simple device of buying the Elders shares in the name of a subsidiary company and then selling the company rather than the shares? Does the Minister realise that Mr Holmes a'Court's manoeuvre has deprived the Government of approximately $7.5m in revenue? As this tax avoidance device has been used several times before, why has the Government failed to take any action to close the loophole? Is the Minister aware of prevailing expert opinion that the proposed new catch-all provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act designed to pick up all tax avoidance schemes will probably be ineffective in the case of this device? If this is true, what action is the Government planning to take in order to prevent a repetition of this extremely expensive occurrence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The reports of profits made by the Bell group of companies in relation to shares in the Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort company have been noted. The Treasurer has commented that the secrecy provisions of the income tax law prevent the Commissioner of Taxation from informing either him or any other person about the tax consequences of this case. The Treasurer, however, stated that he is in a position to speak in general terms about relevant provisions of law. Section 23AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act is one relevant provision. It applies to make taxable profits realised on the disposal of any property that is sold within 12 months of its acquisition.

ANSWER.PARA: There is also section 26 (a) which specifically requires the inclusion in assessable income of profits arising from the sale of property acquired by a taxpayer for the purpose of profit-making by sale or from the carrying on or carrying out of any profit-making undertaking or scheme. There is still another provision-section 25 I-which is of general application and which in broad terms makes assessable any business profits which can be characterised as income as that term is ordinarily understood. I understand that the Treasurer has already indicated that if any undue weakness in the tax law in this area were demonstrated, he would recommend appropriate amendments to the Government. I will seek from the Treasurer comment with regard to the last part of the question asked by Senator Chipp.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I say, with respect, that the question has not been answered by the Minister. I pointed out that a person, by using the device of buying Elders shares in the name of a subsidiary company and then selling the company rather than the shares, avoided the capital gains tax which the Minister in her answer stated was applicable if a transaction took place within 12 months. In my question I enumerated a device by which that section can be overcome. I am not terribly impressed by an answer which says that that section catches a capital gains tax transaction when in fact this person and his colleagues, by this transaction, escaped paying $7.5m in tax. If I may, I press the question: As the Government knows about these loopholes and has recognised them in the columns of the Press, what specific action has the Government in mind to close that loophole?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer that aspect of the question also to the Treasurer and seek an early response from him on it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. To what extent does the Government subsidise diesel fuel and other fuels used in the mining industry in remote areas? Will the Government take into consideration the cost of diesel fuel to opal miners in Coober Pedy and in similar mining areas such as Mintabie and Andamooka in South Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Government's policy regarding the subsidisation of both diesel and petroleum fuels relates, first of all, to the freight subsidy scheme which virtually equalises the wholesale price in the metropolitan area and the country. The retail price, of course, is a question for State governments. Equally, there is no road tax on diesel fuel used off roads on farms or in other undertakings. I have received representations from the mining community at Coober Pedy. I sympathise with the miners in their problems. They explain that they now have high costs and, in particular, the high cost of explosives.

ANSWER.PARA: I pointed out that the fundamental need for us is to ensure that for the future there is available in Australia a sufficiency of middle distillates-the diesels and gasoline. That is the primary task and the main thrust of our energy policies. Secondary to that we are aiming to produce those fuels and to supply them to the community at a lower cost than virtually anywhere else in the world. We are supplying gasoline at about half the price it is in Europe and Japan.

I have reiterated to them the freight subsidisation scheme. The primary thing we must do is to ensure the supply of fuels. In a world in which fuel is dear, obviously our fuel cannot be cheap. Nevertheless, we are providing it at prices which are far more competitive than those in most other countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Pensioners receiving a small additional income from superannuation, bank interest on savings or, perhaps, part time employment are being more and more disadvantaged as they move up the income scale, despite the fact that increases in income in no way match the increases in the consumer price index. When does the Government intend to revise the allowable income table for pensioners, many of whom are now losing their pensions or their benefits?

—Small increases in pensioners' incomes should not result in their receiving total amounts which are less than the increase in the cost of living. The income test which was introduced by the Government in 1976 provides for the withdrawal of pension income at the rate of 50c for every additional dollar of income. A pensioner who receives additional payments of income therefore is better off, and of course, also has the benefit of the twice-yearly indexation of pensions which was put in statutory form by this Government. There are problems for pensioners who get into the taxable area, and that does result in a higher withdrawal rate than 50c in the dollar. But the fact remains that their position still is improved. It has not improved by as much as they would wish but there is no point at which a pensioner's income actually goes backwards.
—What about the pensioner medical card?

—There is a quite separate problem with respect to fringe benefits. The honourable senator opposite is assisting me in making sure that I answer the question totally. It is true that when one gets to the income limits at which the pensioner medical card ceases to be available there is a substantial loss of benefits, and that can be regarded as a matter of considerable hardship by a pensioner. At the same time if we are to maintain any rules which aim to ensure that the available finance is directed to those who are most needy, it is necessary to have income tests and cut-off points. It is difficult to avoid there being cut-off points which are seen as inconvenient or even creating hardship. The matter which has been raised by the honourable senator is one which certainly has exercised my mind and, I am sure, the mind of my predecessor and indeed the minds of her predecessors. To date the Government has not been able to introduce anything which would remove that sudden cut-off of the fringe benefits. I can say, however, that the matter is continuing to receive attention, and it may be that we will come up with some better solution for the future.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Is the Government aware of the enormous harm and damage being done to the pig industry through imports of subsidised hams and pig meats from communist countries such as Romania and Yugoslavia under brand names such as Trump and Yugo which has resulted in the closure of canning plants in Victoria and in Queensland? Further, is the Government aware that the firms which are importing these pig meats already have large quantities of labels ready to be used for the importation of canned beef unless the present policy on pig meats is altered? Will the Minister urge the Government to take immediate action to counter the disastrous situation which has developed in the pig industry and the one which is about to develop in the beef industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of concern which has been expressed in parts of Australia about the importing of ham and the effect that that is having on local industry. The matter was indeed raised some time ago in the Senate by Senator Primmer with respect to Victoria and I think I wrote to him about a week ago giving him a response to the matter which he had raised. The honourable senator from Queensland has pointed out that the problem is one which is not confined to Victoria but also one which is of concern to growers in Queensland. As I have already advised Senator Primmer, but not on the public record, in fact the Government has taken action in this area. There has been an increase in the imports of canned ham. In 1980 there were imports of 907 tonnes compared with 126 tonnes in 1979. This gave rise to claims by domestic canners that imports were being dumped.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Business and Consumer Affairs instituted an inquiry into imports from the two countries mentioned by Senator Bjelke-Petersen-Romania and Yugoslavia-which are the main suppliers of the increased amounts of ham being imported. In January the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs announced that its Minister had accepted price undertakings from both countries not to sell below normal values, and the inquiry was terminated. The Government has taken other action, though. The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs sent a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission which included a request to examine and report within 12 months on the need for long term assistance for canned and bottled meats and to report within 75 days on whether short term assistance was necessary for the canned ham industry. The confidential report of the IAC on that matter has been completed. It is not a public document. Consideration of the report by the Government is expected in the very near future.

With regard to the second part of the honourable senator's question, I was not aware and I do not think the Minister was aware of any firm holding large quantities of labels ready for use on imported beef. If the honourable senator has particulars of this matter she might like to let me or the Minister for Primary Industry have them so that the matter can be examined and appropriate action taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I refer to the question that I asked the Minister last week concerning the possibility of a boycott of the Commonwealth Games in Brisbane next year. As this matter has been reported in detail in the media and in editorials in a number of newspapers since then, is he now in a position to make a statement on the possibility of withdrawing the invitation to New Zealand in order that the games can take place?

—My recollection is that I promised Senator Sibraa that I would make representations to my colleague as a result of the question he asked last week. Those representations will have gone to the Minister by now but I am still awaiting a response from my colleague. For that reason I am not in a position to make the definitive response which he seeks today.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Finance. The Northern Territory Government's plans to introduce permanent part time employment within the Northern Territory Public Service have been delayed by the reluctance of the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office to arrange superannuation coverage for permanent part time employees. Can the Minister indicate, firstly, whether the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office intends eventually to provide such coverage? If it does, what are the reasons for the delay? Secondly, when is it anticipated that the issue will be resolved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The introduction of permanent part time employment in the Australian Public Service and other areas of Commonwealth employment is currently under consideration by the Public Service Board and other employing authorities such as Telecom Australia. Consequently, the Department of Finance has been examining the superannuation arrangements that might be provided under the Superannuation Act 1976 to permanent part time employees. Northern Territory employees comprise a relatively small proportion of the number of contributors to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. It would therefore not be appropriate to consider extending cover under the Superannuation Act to permanent part time employees of the Northern Territory before decisions have been taken in relation to the terms and conditions to apply to permanent part time employment in the Commonwealth generally. Such terms and conditions are primarily the responsibility of the employing authorities. I understand that the matter may take some time to resolve, but arrangements have been made to keep the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory informed of progress. As I said, it is a fairly complex matter and it may take some time but I undertake to keep the Chief Minister informed.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer the Minister to his statement on the social impact of uranium mining on the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory. In that statement he commented on the expressed concern over the intrusion into Aboriginal land of unauthorised visitors. For instance, he advised that a checkpoint and boom gate would be established on the road leading to Oenpelli. Is the Minister aware that the Press in the Northern Territory reports that the Northern Territory Government is advising mining companies that Arnhem Land will be opened up for mining exploration? Has the Northern Territory Government the authority to allow mining exploration in this Aboriginal area? Does the Minister approve of this intrusion of miners into Arnhem Land without the Aboriginal people being consulted? Can the Minister guarantee the rights of Aboriginal people under these circumstances?

—The honourable senator is correct in saying that in the report which I brought to the Senate-we do so regularly-on the social impact of uranium mining the matters of the boom gate and access to Arnhem Land were raised as issues that had concerned some of the traditional owners in Oenpelli and in the area of western Arnhem Land. I am not aware of the reports from the Northern Territory to which the honourable senator adverted. It is quite clear that any mining in the Northern Territory which is to take place on Aboriginal land would have to take place under the provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. The Act lays down quite specifically the process to be followed by anyone wishing to mine on Aboriginal land insofar as it requires the land council in question to negotiate upon the instructions of the traditional owners and the Minister to issue certificates stating that he is happy that particular processes laid down in the Act have been properly carried out. I know of no reason why we would be departing from the provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act insofar as they relate to Aboriginal permission, to consultation with Aboriginals and to the other matters of concern to the honourable senator.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I referred the Minister to the fact that the Press in the Northern Territory stated that the Northern Territory Government will allow mining exploration in the area referred to. Do the same Act and the same provisions which apply to exploration apply to mining?

—As I said, if exploration does occur on Aboriginal land, again the Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act determines certain matters in relation to Aboriginal permission. Not all land, of course, in the Northern Territory is Aboriginal land. Some of that land would come under the provisions of Northern Territory Government legislation; that is a separate matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PAYMENT OF PENSIONS TO VETERANS OVERSEAS

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs by saying that the Minister may remember a question I asked a week or two ago concerning the payment of pensions, other than Service pensions, overseas. Is the Minister able to confirm that an ex-serviceman receiving a Service pension who goes to live outside Australia loses that pension permanently? How long can an ex-serviceman live outside the country before losing the pension permanently? If this is an exact statement of the situation, does it show discrimination unfair to those who fought for our country?

—I will have to confirm several of the facts asserted by Senator Townley. I think that he is referring in particular to disability-type pensions rather than Service pensions. I will undertake to do that and bring down a reply for him as quickly as possible.

—I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy whether the Australian Atomic Energy Commission has a file on the work and deaths of the late Doctors Dalton and Bogle, both eminent scientists? Was certain of the information on the files supplied from the American base at Pine Gap? If such a file is in existence, will the Minister make the file available to the Senate?

—I saw in the Press recently certain assertions regarding the deaths of Dr Bogle and Mrs Chandler and I inquired of the Atomic Energy Commission whether it had any such files. —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction been drawn to statements by the Tasmanian Minister for Housing and Construction that the Federal Government has reneged on its welfare housing offer to the States? Will the Minister assure this place that the Government is not opting out of welfare housing assistance to the States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention was drawn to this matter. It has been in the Press, not only in Tasmania but also in other States, I believe. The facts regarding the arrangements, as I understand them, are that the Commonwealth, in its original offer to the States on the post-1981 welfare housing arrangements, offered base level funding of $200m each year for five years. The Commonwealth stressed that this was a base level funding only and that total funding would be decided each year in the Budget, whereas I believe Mr Baldock was making the point that no such arrangement existed.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth proposed that some $50m of the $200m should be earmarked for innovative projects. The majority of the States, in their responses to the Commonwealth's offer, indicated that they did not want these funds earmarked for special projects; they wanted freedom to decide how these funds could be best spent. The Commonwealth, after considering those views, decided that each State should have complete freedom to decide how it would spend these funds. Accordingly, a revised offer was put to the States. That meant the retention of the $200m per annum forward commitment. Of that amount, $54m was for pensioners and Aboriginals. States are completely free to determine the allocation of the other $146m. Incidentally, that money is provided at the highly concessional interest rate of 4 1/2 per cent.
The Commonwealth has not reneged on its offer. It has given the States greater freedom to decide how their funds should be spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about all this money though?

—The forward commitment that the States have sought for many years has been retained at $200m per annum. Total funds-I emphasise for Senator Coleman's benefit-will be decided each year in the Commonwealth Budget. A State can use its total funds available to it-both Commonwealth and State-to carry out a wide range of innovative projects, if it so desires. Instead of the Commonwealth dictating what is to be done in the welfare housing area, it is now up to the State to make effective use of the funds made available in such a way as it determines.
