SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

I take this opportunity to comment briefly on the tabling of these two very important reports of the Tertiary Education Commission and the Schools Commission. By way of preliminary remark, I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that they recommend guidelines for funding for the years 1982 to 1984. The report of the Tertiary Education Commission also reviews tertiary education in Australia from 1975 to 1980.

I remind the Senate of the diversity of the tertiary education sector, which now embraces 19 universities, 69 colleges of advanced education, about 200 major technical and further education colleges with 900 annexes and other institutions. Involved in all these institutions are approxi- mately 800,000 students, including, of course, part time students. Approximately 41,000 academic staff and over 40,000 other staff are involved also. The total financial assistance from governments in 1980 was in the order of $2,100m, of which 80 per cent came from the Commonwealth Government. From these reports it appears that in the tertiary education sector, as might be expected, the rate of growth in enrolments is declining. The balance of the rate of growth is moving away from the university and CAE sectors into the TAFE sector, but overall it can clearly be said that a no-growth position has been reached.

What I particularly want to draw attention to, what I argue emerges from these reports, is that the Government's education policy is becoming increasingly out of step with its professed development policies. It is frequently said in this chamber, and of course we have debated it from time to time, that we are on the eve of a resources boom.

This is perhaps in some ways very encouraging but it will not be sufficient. It is not sufficient to say this unless, if I may put it this way, the knee bone is related to the thigh bone in government policies. The implications of this are seen in respect of the education sector. If any honourable senator on the Government side need further detailed information about this, I commend to them a number of papers on these topics which were published by a former shadow Minister for Education and which deal very thoroughly with the areas to which I refer.

What is needed in the education sector are policies which are designed, in some respects at least to ensure that jobs flow from the development of those education policies, and particularly in relation to high technology industries. We need education policies designed for the 1980s. Somebody said about this country quite recently that we are now beginning to grapple very satisfactorily with the issues of the 1960s and that somebody looking at this society from outside would be pardoned for assuming that we are mildy retarded as a society.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should acknowledge your source.

—I think it was the distinguished shadow Minister for Science and Technology in the House of Representatives who said that. I am indebted to Senator Martin for prompting me. I overlooked it for a moment. In connection with the need for policies for the 1980s I refer the Senate to pages 266 and 267 of the summary of the Tertiary Education Commission's recommendations for 1982-84. On page 266, the Commission refers to 'an increased likelihood of structural and technological changes in the economy which may require men and women to change occupations during their working lives'. The Commission went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Training institutions should continually examine the relevance of the courses they offer in terms of their broader value as well as their specific vocational purpose . . .

It seems to me, if I may make the comment, that in this report the Tertiary Education Commission is at last getting to grips with the nub of that rather silly argument that has gone on as to whether one is a generalist or a vocationalist in relation to education. I think that is an important step forward because that argument is one in which people have always taken rather fixed positions and sides and it seems to me that what we should be seeking in the education system is broad general education as the TEC report points to, having regard to likely social and technological changes. But within that context, there is, of course, no necessary objection to, no reason why there should not be, quite specific vocational elements related to technological change. In fact, just a few minutes ago I saw a newspaper article about Canada and its specific educational emphasis on high technology and the efforts of the Canadian Government in effect to establish, related to Canadian universities in the west of Canada, a sort of silicon valley complex for Canada in terms of applied and pure research in relation to technology. On page 267 of the report, there is also an important reference to the training of engineers in Australia, engineering being a profession which has become the classic example of lack of foresight in terms of manpower training considerations.

I would argue that the Government has failed consistently to give any lead in relation to some of the education issues which are now raised in these reports. There have been a number of marginal belt tightening diversions by the Government in terms of restrictions on study leave, fees for overseas students, the pursuit of student organisations for one idealogical reason or another, and things of that kind but they are not in any sense new or major initiatives relating to the important central issues in education which should be concerning us.

When a government controls, as this one does, the tertiary education sector, it cannot in any sense be laissez-faire control; that is to say, a government has obligations in respect of the overall guidelines and leadership which it sets. In that context, the Tertiary Education Commission report asks for several things. First of all, it asks for broader based courses to cope with technological change. I have referred already to paragraph 9.32 on page 266 in the summary of recommendations which deals specifically with that issue. Secondly, the report deals with the question of rationalisation. There has been a lot of discussion of rationalisation of tertiary education institutions. I think it tends to be conceded across party lines that we have too many such institutions. The question is: What does one do about it? Does one take the steps that the Callaghan Government in Britain took when it closed about five institutions in one week, or does one try to work out other methods of rationalisation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the steps taken in Tasmania?

—Not five in one week, Senator. It was more like one in five years in Tasmania. The important question is how one tackles rationalisation and on page 268 the report deals with that question. At paragraph 9.42 the Commission, whether one agrees with its view or not, comes to grips with the question of teacher education and, in particular, what it sees as the 'redirection of effort' as it calls it. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission supports a major redirection of effort in advanced education from teacher education to the technologies and business studies . . .

In paragraph 9.42 of the report the Commission goes on to say how it believes that result can best be achieved. I quite appreciate that the Commission in dealing with that issue in this way is ignoring the argument about how many teachers are needed in society, what the teacher-pupil ratio should be, and so on. But, within the limitations in which the TEC operates and under the guidelines under which it operates, it at least has grappled with the issue raised in that paragraph to which I referred.

The views set out in the report of the TEC are in a sense very strongly reinforced and supplemented by the report of the Australian Schools Commission. I, like other honourable senators, have not had a chance to read all of that report. Really, these sorts of reports ought to be discussed in great detail in this Parliament because for the first time, I think, they start to go to the heart of the issues which should be the concern of those involved in the political debate about education in this country. The Schools Commission report at page 14 and in adjacent pages discusses in some detail the question of youth unemployment. One of the things mentioned on page 14-I suppose in a sense it seems to encapsulate something of the problem-is that the Commission feels that terms such as 'new underclass', as used by Husen, and 'residual group' which originated in Denmark capture the essence of the problem. The Commission is talking about the fact that the schools system is not adequately catering for a section of the school population and that this will lead in society to the development of what the Commission in this context calls a new underclass. That has a melodramatic flavour about it, but in a sense it does perhaps capture the important point which the Schools Commission is trying to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a most important one.

—Yes, I agree; it is a point of the utmost importance. The Australian Schools Commission report also talks about 'learning for life' and the question of 'adaptability'. In a sense this complements the reference in the Tertiary Education Commission report to the need for broad educational goals to be set in the interests of adaptability for students of tertiary education institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: I hesitate to do this but I commend to honourable senators the first chapter of the Schools Commission report because it takes up a number of issues which were dealt with in a document called 'Education and National Aims' put out a year or so ago. I also commend that document to honourable senators to read. If they read that statement called 'Education and National Aims', a speech delivered, I think, at Townsville in May last year, they will see that the Schools Commission has in fact taken up many of the issues raised in that statement, including the necessity for the education system to be concerned with questions of social cohesion and the relevance of the economic relationship between this country and the neighbouring countries of South East Asia in a situation in which the economies of many of those countries are developing rapidly and having regard to the importance for Australia of being able to have a better interchange than we have been able to have in the past not only in terms of language which is very important but also in terms of the exchange of technology and so on. I believe that that is a matter of vital relevance which the Schools Commission has taken up. I noted in today's Canberra Times a report by Professor Karmel, the Chairman of the Tertiary Education Commission, which deals with some of the issues I referred to in both the Tertiary Education Commission report and the Schools Commission report. The article states:

Education should have a broad outlook and cater to the need for social and intellectual development of individuals in areas including politics and economics, the chairman of the Tertiary Education Commission, Professor Peter Karmel, said at the weekend.
He said:
. . . there were dangers in imparting too narrow a vocational perspective to education.
Knowledge of the world of work, including knowledge of why different kinds of work command different rewards, was not vocational education, he said.
He further said:

It is important to emphasise that the teaching of specific skills at schools will not in itself create jobs, although young people with those skills may be in a better position to compete for the jobs available. It is also important to emphasise that vocational training at school is not an essential element in informing students about the nature of work and in creating more positive attitudes to work.

The article continues at some greater length. I want to make the point that Professor Karmel made in the newspaper article, no doubt with the knowledge that the TEC report would be tabled at this time. The article involves a point which I think we should face up to in the so-called education debate. I refer to the lack of Government response for nearly six years, the parsimony of funding in some areas and the very little imagination shown in relation to education policies. In 1981 with the advantage of these reports perhaps we can get more expressions of hope and new education policies than we have had in the past. Both the reports are forward-looking documents. I believe that it is very much up to the Government to respond responsibly to the reports.

In referring to the Schools Commission report may I also pay a very sincere tribute which is both a personal tribute and a party tribute to the former chairman of the Schools Commission, Dr Ken McKinnon. Whatever virtues people may see in the new chairman, I think it is true to say that Dr McKinnon presided over the Schools Commission with imagination and compassion and, if I might say so, with a very steady nerve because the Schools Commission, in the last few years, had something of a tightrope to walk. I think that Dr McKinnon was able to keep together a number of forces in education which might have become very hostile and, in a sense, disintegrated. He created in the Schools Commission a state of mind whereby it was capable of appreciating the views of others.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have any thoughts as to why he was not reappointed?
—No, I have not. I think it represents a crisis of imagination and nerve more of the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) than of Dr McKinnon.
—I did not know the Minister had either of those things.

—I cannot handle that interjection. I would have to recast my whole line of thought to handle that. But assuming that the Minister had any nerve and imagination then he suffered a crisis in relation to those things when he failed to re-appoint Dr McKinnon as chairman of the Schools Commission. I believe, no matter what anybody else might like to say, that Dr McKinnon has been a great Australian public servant. In his chairmanship of the Schools Commission he displayed his talents to the full. The Government has made a decision about appointing a new chairman. I wish him well and hope that he has the same imagination and nerve as Dr McKinnon had. I hope this Government will not overlook the very real qualities that Dr McKinnon has and what he has to offer to this country and that he will not be left languishing in some research job, or something of that kind, when his talents and integrity are much greater than deserving of that. I hope those matters will be taken account of by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other comment I want to make at this stage is to speak briefly about the relationship between education and the so-called resources boom. It seems to me there are a number of impedimenta which prevent this country from grappling with some of the issues in the resources boom as we ought to do. I think that many opportunities are being lost to Australia because we are not talking about the right issues in the Australian political debate. We are not addressing our minds, as a country, to anything but rather short-term solutions. Countries I regard as more healthy democracies in the sense of imagination do not seem incapacitated by such problems. I refer to countries such as Norway, Sweden and particularly Holland where, for example, there has been for some time a very conscientious effort to relate aspects of the education system to the industrial development of that country. I refer the Senate to a paper on the management of technological change by Dr J. L. Farrands, Secretary to the Department of Science and Technology. To an international conference of the Australian Academy of Technological Science last year he stated:

The prime characteristic of the Australian way of managing technological change in general, and research and development in particular, is the almost unique absence of central planning. We are, I suppose, as close to laissez faire as it seems possible to be in modern societies.

No doubt for ideological reasons that will strike a warm inner glow in the breasts of some people in this country; the thought that we are as close to laissez-faire as it seems possible to be in a modern society. In relation to technology and education I am not sure that we should be as warmly complacent as that. It seems to be a pretty accurate description of our situation and in my view it is an accurate description of the dilemma we face. Frankly, I believe we have in Australia a respectable research capacity and considerable talent in industry, universities and organisations such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. It is a tragedy that a lot of that talent and work is allowed to drain overseas because of the lack of applied skills and imaginative initiatives in Australia. I believe that we spend too little on research and development. If we are to survive and move ahead as a technologically advanced, export-earning country something has to be done.

I think it is true to say that our research and development effort is biased in favour of basic and government-supported research. There is a need for a lot of encouragement in industrial research and development. There is a need for a lot of flexibility in manpower between industry, universities and the Public Service. These are issues which seem to flow from some of the considerations raised in the report of the Tertiary Education Commission. I will give a very good example of where we have had success in these matters. If I might say so to Senator Scott-it is not my wont to hand out gratuitous compliments to the National Country Party-the history of this country when the bias in Australian research effort was very much, I believe, a result of Country Party pressure significantly loaded in favour of rural industries, we achieved quite outstanding results. Very good relationships were established between government, producer organisations and research effort in this country which produced good results and made our rural industries competitive and very efficient. If we are to achieve anything in employment arising from educational effort, if we are to achieve higher export earnings from manufacturing industry, the same process will have to take place in relation to Australian manufacturing industry and Australian resource development as took place in an earlier period of our history when we got that recognition of the relationship of research to industry and the co-operation between industry, government and research institutions which has done so much for Australian rural industry.

In a small industrial economy such as ours there is a need to make positive decisions to concentrate research and development efforts in particular areas. These are matters which arise from some of the recommendations in the Tertiary Education Commission report. We fancy ourselves, quite properly I think, as a society which has relatively high living and educational standards, much higher than many other countries. Because of the fact that we are European in culture and outlook, we regard ourselves as a developed country. In the economic sense we will not remain a developed country unless we give much more attention to the issues which are raised in these reports. I sincerely commend the contents of these reports for serious consideration and debate in this Parliament in the next few weeks or months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few remarks on both the Tertiary Education Commission report and the Schools Commission report which have been tabled today. Whilst I disagree with many of the conclusions that have been drawn by Senator Button, there are at least two matters that I do not depart from. One is the importance of providing an opportunity for general education issues to be aired in the way that they are being aired briefly today, although it is extremely difficult to comment when one is faced with a report of the Schools Commission which runs into some 500 pages, and six volumes from the Tertiary Education Commission. Both are substantial reports and set the ground rules which will change the nature and shape of Australian education in the years to come. The other point in which I concur with some of the remarks made by Senator Button, is about the contribution made by Dr McKinnon to the work of the Schools Commission over the years that he was chairman.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make a few remarks about the Schools Commission report but confine most of them to the Tertiary Education Commission report. If honourable senators look at page 27 of the Schools Commission report, they will see a table which shows the relative enrolment between government and non-government schools. The table shows that from a high point in 1905, when 81.1 per cent of children were in government schools and 18.9 per cent were at non-government schools, the change in enrolment has been quite significant. Now we are looking at 77.7 per cent in government schools and 22.3 per cent in non-government schools. In the period from 1975 to 1980 the change in enrolment between government and non-government schools shows a decline of one per cent at the government level and a corresponding increase of one per cent at the non-government level.

The Schools Commission, in coming up with its specific recommendations, has turned its attention to one of the funding aspects. It recommended that Federal contribution to recurrent costs for government schools be increased from $230m in 1981 to $237m in 1984 and that the corresponding figure for non-government schools be $317m in 1981 and $369m in 1984. This represents an increase of $52m for the non-government sector, compared with $7m for the public sector. Frankly, if that trend persists I think we will see a revival of the worst form of sectional and sectarian disagreement in the Australian education system that we have been cursed with for a long time. Those sorts of disparities are becoming intolerable. I believe in the provision of government assistance to non-government schools. As a matter of principle, I always have. My education was entirely in government schools. I appreciate the argument put by people in the non-government sector about the amount of catching up that they have to do. That is undoubtedly true. There are still-probably my school in Sydney is one that falls into this category-government schools which are also substantially in need of an increase in their resources and allocations.

I think in the middle 1960s one of the debates that was bitter and divisive in the Australian community was the general so-called state aid debate. It has been largely laid to rest as a political issue. It has now largely been laid to rest as a constitutional issue. If we are to see $52m spent in the non-government sector in a brief period, compared with only $7m in the government sector-which services roughly four times the number of children at school-we will need a far more penetrating debate about the relative value and merit of the way in which we allocate resources to schools. We made commitments in the policy speech about the way in which the six levels of the old Karmel scheme would be compressed into three and how we would achieve certain targets as far as resource allocation for non-government schools is concerned. I do not cavil for one minute at these views, but I raise a warning that if those figures fail to be understood, analysed and above all justified by governments in the education debate, the issue of community divisiveness which would otherwise be present, but I think not at the highest level in the education debate, would surface again to the detriment of the education system, to the detriment of the political system and above all to the detriment of the kids in schools. That is a very important matter for a government to come to grips with when it is looking at its response to the Schools Commission. The Schools Commission recognises this. In paragraph 3.34, after discussing, in a chapter, the relative public and private schooling issues, the Commission states:

This is a situation which cannot be left simply to drift to a point where the community is polarised. It is time to consider and introduce gradually to both government and non-government sectors a means of orderly development which meets the wishes of Australian society. Unless this is done, increased difficulties and even divisions are inevitable.

Nothing could prejudice the future of the Australian nation more than its entering the decade of the 1980s and beyond with a division and polarisation about the rights of kids at school and the necessity to come to grips with those issues.

I turn to the Tertiary Education Commission report and congratulate the Commission and Professor Karmel on bringing down what I think is probably the most useful set of reports that the Tertiary Education Commission has produced. This sets us off in a large number of new directions-new areas-and comes to grips, as Senator Button said, with fundamental issues. One of the great problems that has plagued the post-secondary education debate in Australia has been a failure to understand where the various responsibilities of the universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education colleges begin and end, where they shade into each other and where they are distinct. One of the things which the TEC report has done-and done most successfully-is to sharpen those lines of delineation, to say what is appropriate to universities, to CAEs, and to TAFE institutions. It has come to grips with that, in particular, on the question of research. Volume 1, Part 1, paragraph 6.28 of the Commission's report states:

The Commission believes that the academic staff of universities and CAEs should be involved in scholarship, research and public service. Universities and CAEs both have a commitment to teach undergraduates, but universities have a special institutional commitment to scholarship and research and to training scholars and research workers. They are funded accordingly. CAEs do not have such a commitment, although individual staff members should be expected, and indeed encouraged, to undertake activities of this type with an emphasis on practical application.

It goes on to make funding recommendations accordingly. I think it is terribly important to start understanding the pressure that is coming from CAEs. They want additional moneys to fund research and the Commission has said: 'No, the research cake is limited and, with only the most minor deviations, that research money is more appropriately expended through the universities'. It goes on to make recommendations about the colleges granting masters degrees, and a very strong recommendation that they should not even think about getting into the doctorate of philosophy process.

The next thing I would identify in the TEC report is that despite all the wind and rhetoric that we heard on the question of study leave when the TEC's report on study leave was produced and presented, the evidence that comes forward in the report is that the new study leave arrangements have worked pretty well, that there has been a considerable increase in the amount of study leave taken in Australia as distinct from overseas and that, although in some institutions it is still outside the guidelines that the TEC would have liked to have established, the TEC's recommendations by and large are falling into place and the roof is not falling in on the universities or the standard of scholarship at universities.

The report is significant in making recommendations about the rationalisation and the sharing of library services. This is a very important matter for universities, particularly as the cost of journals escalates year by year. I think the recommendations that the TEC puts forward in this area are again very important. Senator Button has already referred to the rationalisation of institutions. The TEC not only makes recommendations about the teachers colleges at Newcastle, Townsville and Goulburn and various other institutions, but also balances that with an appreciation of what is politically possible, when, like many of us, it says: 'Oh that we had managed to get some sensible solution to the problems of Murdoch University and the University of Western Australia, but we all recognise that there are forces operating in the west which are greater than any of us as far as this particular educational priority is concerned. Therefore we will see whether we can do something about sharing services and recognise that we are not going to win the battle about amalgamation or federation of those universities, but at least we are not going to let it pass without comment'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the proposition that there are forces operating in the west greater than any of us a general one or only an educational one?

—No, I never despair on these things. I think if we get in first we can succeed even as far as that is concerned; it is once we let the matter get beyond the stage where rationality can be reintroduced that we are unsuccessful. Although Senator Button somewhat made light of the--
—You are not referring to a recent Queensland senatorial appointment, I hope.

—I am not referring to anything of the kind. Although Senator Button somewhat made light of the changes that have taken place in Tasmania, I think it is significant that at least in that State, with some considerable disruption to its education system, there has been an attempted rationalisation of the campus facilities-one which again was resisted, as one would have expected, but which has been pushed through successfully. I am delighted to see that a series of new initiatives is recommended by the Commission, even though the general thrust of the report is one of restraint. I think it is very important that we identify these without saying anything substantial about them. It recommends that in some Australian university-not a specific university-a school of fisheries should be established. It recognises the importance of the fishing industry, and its relevance given the new declarations about the management of the coastal zone, the 200-mile limit and the exploitations of resources.
—That suggestion comes from that Townsville speech to which I referred you.

—I am quite persuaded that the TEC has better and more adequate sources of input than Townsville speeches. I am sure that the TEC would not be persuaded just because somebody happened to be campaigning in Townsville to the effect that some such school ought to be established at the James Cook University. The Commission goes on to recommend the establishment of a school of business studies at the Adelaide College of the Arts and Education, development in community language teaching, an additional 350 places in nurse education, additional feeder courses for CAEs which are becoming involved with the applied sciences and humanity courses, two-tier courses and bridging courses. I think it is very important that those things have been clearly identified as new initiatives, as indeed has been the proposal for a temporary development grant which is dealt with in paragraph 9.42 on page 268 of the summary document. In that paragraph the Commission states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission proposes that temporary development grants should be provided for the advanced education sector for the two years 1982 and 1983 to enable it to support the expansion of enrolments in the technologies and business studies ahead of the release of resources from teacher education.

What that says is that teacher education is to be phased down, that when it is phased down to a more appropriate level new resources will become available and that those resources should then be transferred to business courses and management courses where appropriate, but that until that money has been released from one sector these temporary development grants should be made available. The Commission is still working on the centres of excellence program which was announced in the policy speech. We hope that in the not too distant future these will be specifically identified. An amount of $1m in the first year and then $15m over a five-year program is to be expended on centres of excellence. I know that the Commission has that matter well in hand.

The final general point I wish to make about the Commission's report is that it comes to grips at last with the question of building. It states very specifically that because of the decline in future enrolments-the steadying of enrolments-there is no need for great expenditure on building, but that the building grants will go up from something like $36m to $50m over each of the next three years and that that should be sufficient for maintenance and emergency new works. The other very significant point is that the Commission recommends for the first time a very significant thing for universities in particular-the triennial funding of equipment. In the past universities have had to operate on the basis that if they want a very expensive piece of machinery-a cyclotron or something that will involve the expenditure of many millions of dollars-they might save up their money and in one year make that investment, with no guarantee that in the next year they would be able to pay anything towards that cost. Here is a recommendation for triennial equipment funding so that expensive pieces of equipment and equipment that needs to be repaired can be paid for out of money granted over a three-year period. That is something for which the universities have been pressing for a long time. I know that it will be welcomed by them.

I conclude by saying something very quickly about the patterns that the TEC identifies. One is the enormous change in the nature of the student population in Australia. It is increasingly a part time rather than a full time population. Studies programs are increasingly external rather than internal. There is an increasingly older, more mature group of students than was previously the case and overwhelmingly, the population is now becoming a female one rather than a predominantly male one. Those things are all taken up by the Commission. They are all discussed by the Commission and recommendations arise as to the appropriate way in which to respond to those challenges.

Universities' rates of growth have declined dramatically. In 1975 they were growing at the rate of 3.8 per cent. They are now growing at the rate of about one half per cent. Enrolments in colleges of advanced education have moved only from 125,000 to 165,000 in the last five years. By contrast, enrolments in the TAFE institutions have moved from 521,000 to 654,000. Their rate of growth, which was 6.6 per cent in 1976, has remained rather steady at 5.8 per cent, 5.5 per cent and 5.5 per cent respectively in each of the subsequent three years. In the triennium 1982-84 which this report covers, universities are projected to have no real growth in student numbers, colleges of advanced education are projected to have 1.5 per cent growth and TAFE institutions 9 per cent growth. If we look at the recommendations we can see that this report recognises the real need of the TAFE sector and goes a long way towards identifying the fact-indeed, it says this-that that is where more and more of our post-secondary resources must be concentrated. The criticism Senator Button made about the relationship of education expenditure to the resources boom I think equally has to be seen in the context of the TEC recommendations on expenditure on TAFE, tradesmen and skilled workers.

The dramatic change in the behaviour of young people in Australia is reflected in these reports. In 1974 in excess of 18 per cent of 17-year-olds went straight from school to university. In 1980 that figure fell to about 14.5 per cent. That is a fall of something like a quarter of the number of people going straight from school to university. That has enormous social and educational implications. This report starts to come to grips with those implications. I welcome the opportunity to make those few remarks on both of these significant reports. What they mean for the future of education in Australia is dramatic and significant. I hope that the Government will be able to take up the recommendations made. Financially they are modest in terms of organisation, they are efficient and, indeed, they are far-sighted. Both Professor Karmel and Dr McKinnon deserve to be congratulated on their production. I hope that the Parliament and the education debate in Australia will be greatly advanced by having these documents available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I compliment both Senator Button and Senator Puplick on two very thoughful speeches. I agree with almost everything both of them have said. I too would like to pay a tribute, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, to the retiring Chairman of the Schools Commission, Dr McKinnon. I commend the Australian for an article which appeared in its issue of Friday, 27 March, and from which I will quote. It is a most excellent extract for students of the education debate. It analyses the reports of both the Tertiary Education Commission and the Schools Commission. The article had this to say about Dr McKinnon:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the report, which will attact interest not least because it is the last by the commission's past chairman, Dr K. R. McKinnon.
Although not printed until after his January departure, the report still has the flavour of Dr McKinnon's wide-ranging and humane interest in education.

I am sure that all senators agree with that statement. We are very critical though of Dr McKinnon's removal from the position of Chairman of the Schools Commission. He was making a great contribution to Australian education. We strongly suspect that he was relieved of his post owing to his well-founded criticism of some aspects of the way in which education operates in this country. Of all Dr McKinnon's worries and prognoses the one which seemed to concern him most is the one to which Senator Puplick referred. I want to amplify that matter which is dealt with on pages 26 and 27 of the report. It concerns increased funding to non-government schools and, indeed, the increased number of children attending non-government schools vis-a-vis government schools. I was very interested by, if not surprised at, the vehemence with which Senator Puplick approached the problem. He saw it as being a problem of great division in the future. I had not quite put it in that perspective. Nonetheless I share his concern over it. Let two things be said about the policy of the Democrats. The first paragraph of our education policy concerning state aid states:
. . . our ultimate objective would be to make the State system of education so good that no one would need or want to send their child to a non-State school.

However, we go on to say that there is a need and an equity of people who choose to send their children to a non-government school to receive some share of the cake. In fact, I have the doubtful honour-I do not regard it as doubtful; some people would-of being the first member of a Federal parliament to have advocated state aid. That was in 1962. It is interesting to reflect that at that time I was almost sent to Coventry by my colleagues in the Liberal Party of Australia and I was certainly ignored by members of the Australian Labor Party for posing such an outrageous suggestion. In politics it is funny sometimes to contemplate how fast matters move. I think one year later then Mr McMahon-this is Sir William McMahon's side of the story-persuaded Sir Robert Menzies to incorporate massive state aid in the 1963 election campaign as a basic policy plank.

We have grave reservations about present government educational policy in general and specifically about the way in which the Government appears to be undermining the independence of the Schools Commission. We are very concerned about the Government's tendency to increase the funding of private schools at the expense of government schools. The Minister for Education, Mr Fife, announced in January that subsidies to wealthy schools would be effectively increased by one-third compared with an increase of only one-quarter in subsidies to poorer schools. Senator Puplick put it in another way; I think it was clearer than that. Whichever way one puts it I think it leads to great concern about this tendency. Between 1974 and 1979 public spending on government schools increased by 10.5 per cent compared with an increase of 32.5 per cent for non-government schools. On 12 January the Age put it rather quaintly and colourfully when it stated:
As the . . . Government continues to close the doors on many of its little red schoolhouses, bright, new and expensive private schools are popping up all over the place.

One wonders whether that is a healthy development in our education system. We agree with the Schools Commission that in a situation in which school enrolments are expected to fall by more than 50,000 in the next three years new non-government schools should not start without considering their impact on the enrolments of existing schools. Now non-government schools must also be able to demonstrate that they will operate at an acceptable standard. I would have loved the Senate to have debated all the education matters at great length this afternoon. There are so many aspects about which I, frankly, do not have a finite or definitive view.

I simply say without argument that in this connection we view with concern the fact that religious fundamentalist schools have begun to proliferate in Australia. The Schools Commission knew of one of these schools in 1977. Now there are at least 60 such schools. That is a growth of 59 schools in three years. There are also at least two Ananda Marga schools and one Hare Krishna school being funded by the Government. One could make an argument from that. One could be shocked and distressed that these kinds of quasi-religious organisations are being funded by taxpayers' money. One could lead a fairly persuasive argument to put a tremor through people about it. Yet if a person did that he would find himself very quickly on the road of arguing for religious freedom for certain religions and non-religious freedom for other religions. Frankly, I do not know what attitude to adopt towards this question of whether these--

TALK.START.PARA: —Give nothing to any of them.

—That would cure the problem but I do not know whether it would be a good cure. I think it would be a little over-simplistic. To what extent should we go in funding these sorts of schools? If some ideology which was perilously close to communism without its revolutionary anti-law concepts applied for money for a State school, should we give it to that group?
—What about the Scientologists?

—Scientology. One could go on, but to what extent? Where do we draw the line? I say frankly that I just do not know. I wish that this debate could have gone on a little longer so that at least I could have learned something from it. I wonder why parents are now sending their children to non-government schools or private schools rather than to government schools. The figures on pages 26 and 27 of the report which Senator Puplick read out do not help much, as he will agree. The report says that in the five years from 1975 to 1980 one per cent more children went to private schools and one per cent fewer went to government schools. It does not tell us anything about the number of children involved. Although the figure is only one per cent I think the number of children involved would be about 20,000.

SPEECH.PARA: Over a short period many parents have made an overt decision, even in times of economic problems, and have said: 'I will not accept a virtually free government education. I will now opt to send my child or children to an education which will cost a fair bit of money'. As someone who has sent all his children to private schools-it may be that I sent them to private schools because I was not fortunate to enjoy that privilege-I, along with other senators, know the massive costs involved in sending kids to private schools. Many more parents are making this substantial sacrifice. They are saying that they will not spend their money on a holiday or a second car. They are making an overt decision and saying: 'A significant part of our income and our savings will go into our children's education. We will send them to private rather than public schools'. I would like to have heard Senator Button and Senator Puplick give their reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are they doing that?
—I would like Senator O'Byrne to tell me his reasons. Again, I confess ignorance. All I can do--
—It gives them the right contacts for future life. People who get all the privileges in the community get them through the private schools.

—I will not deny that that factor was in my mind when I sent my children to a private school. I went to a state school and those contacts were not available to me. Did I overreact in sending my children to private schools? I do not know. It is a factor that teachers--
—It gives them a bit of polish lacking in their old man.

—Thank you. I acknowledge that interjection in a flash so that it will appear in Hansard. Is it a fact that teachers in the state school system have become slack? I do not say that they have. Have they become slack in the eyes of parents? No doubt the discipline over teachers in state schools is not as hard or as harsh--

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am getting a little more help than I need. I am thankful for the assistance, but it is a little more than I need.
—You are interrupting our speeches.

—I am terribly sorry. I think that many parents take the view that state school teachers are slacker and that they are spreading a philosophy of non-discipline and whatever. I am not saying that teachers do that; I am just saying that parents have that view. I believe that many parents take the view-I do not commend them for this-that if they send their children to a private school they will be given discipline. They see the private schools as exercising a function which the parents themselves should be exercising but choose not to. The parents opt out of that responsibility by allowing the private school to administer that essential ingredient of their child's upbringing. There is no question that the better facilities at private schools are a factor.
—At some private schools. It is not true of most of the small Catholic schools, for instance.

—I thought I was agreeing with Senator Puplick. I was about to make the point that on balance private schools have better sporting, library and other facilities than government schools. I think that that is particularly so in outlying suburbs and is another factor which influences parents.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be that the clock has swung around concerning permissiveness and anti-religious feelings in our community. Because of nuclear threats and the manic behaviour of certain world leaders of both the Left and the Right, many parents are going back to religion and perhaps are feeling that at least if they have to bring up their children in a world that will blow itself apart their children will die having a healthier attitude towards religion. It may be that I am being unfair to the Schools Commission in saying that it did not canvass these issues more and come before the Parliament and the Minister with more definitive reasons as to why this phenomenon of massive numbers of parents changing their children from state schools to public schools is happening in our community. The Australian, commenting on the Schools Commission report, stated:
This has been caused by a wide range of factors . . . including increased recurrent and capital assistance from Commonwealth and State governments for non-government schools.

I take Senator Puplick's point. It is crystal clear that the movement of children from government to non-government schools is being assisted by Commonwealth and State governments. I do not know whether the governments are doing it consciously. I believe that some State governments-as they do with so many things-are doing it unconsciously. I think the Federal Government is doing it subconsciously. It is being done. I appeal to the Government to think of the consequences of such action. I ask it to look at Senator Puplick's speech today and to look at the rather dire prognosis that he put down about what will happen if this trend is not arrested in the near future.

One could go on for a long time. I want to note a few items that I would have liked to have developed in this debate and which I would have liked other honourable senators to have developed to see the Schools Commission and governments be more strong on giving aid, if aid must be given to non-government schools, to single sex schools. Surely to God we have reached a stage in the twentieth century where governments at least realise that single sex schools are an anachronism and a direct cause of anti-social conduct by young people and that they motivate against young people, at a most difficult stage of their lives, having some form of social communication with their peers.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is good evidence that they assist women in their education and that it is good for girls to go to single sex schools; not for social reasons but for educational reasons.

—I have read those sorts of comments. I do not reject them. I have read volumes on the other side of the story. Like the honourable senator undoubtedly, I have been to both types of schools. One makes a judgment of the social consciousness and the educational motivation of students in those schools. As far as I am concerned there is no contest. I think that the single sex school, whether it be for boys or girls, is an anachronism which should have been left behind many years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator Button that there was not enough in the report about mathematics and engineering deficiencies in our education system. I am informed that fewer and fewer children-the proportion is significant-are undertaking mathematics in schools today. That leads to a corresponding diminution in the number of students taking engineering in their tertiary education. The Australian Institute of Engineers is deeply concerned about this trend and points out the inevitability of having to import engineers and technologists within the next five years. I was a little disappointed that the Schools Commission report did not have something new to say about the kind of insanity that we impact on our young children through our secondary education system when they turn 16, 17 or 18 years of age. I am talking about the Higher School Certificate and matriculation. Having had four children who have gone through the agony and having spoken, as have other honourable senators, at secondary schools regularly during the course of the year, I always feel saddened after leaving a school in which we have these beautiful young people to think of their being forced to live the most unnatural year of their life.

I condemn those educators who have not yet developed the wit to test the intellectual capacity of Australia's 16-year-olds, 17-year-olds and 18-year-olds other than by giving them a work load in their matriculation or HSC year three times greater than that which we would expect a normal person to bear. Young persons turning 17 or 18 years of age feel for the first time a social consciousness not only of their environment-the world-but also, certainly, of the opposite sex and of their responsibilities as young adults, with interests fanning out from the three Rs and the narrow confines of their studies. In that year we allow these people of little wit, the educators, to say: 'During this year of your life we will make you work 6 1/2 days a week. You will go to school at 9 o'clock in the morning and when you rush home, after your sandwich at 5 o'clock we will then make you work until 10.30 or 11 o'clock. On Sunday maybe you can have the night off'. I wish Senator Martin, for whom I have unbounded affection, would not be a smart-Alick about those kinds of remarks. If she is, let her go to schools where matriculation classes are taught. Let her ask doctors in her electorate in Queensland how the graph of kids of 17 or 18 doing matriculation or HSC soars during July, August or September. Am I doing Senator Martin an injustice?

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly. I used to teach in a boarding school. I have lived with girls in that position.
—Is the honourable senator agreeing with me?
—My query to you is: Which educators are you being critical of-the teachers or the university people who set the entrance standards?
—The latter. I am sorry I did not make that clear. I apologise for, and withdraw, any reflection on the honourable senator's alleged activities.
—Withdraw the affection.

—I do not withdraw the affection; not on your life. It is a serious matter. We ought to inject more humanity, more compassion and more understanding into what we are inflicting on young people. Those of us in this Parliament should be trying to encourage our young people to improve their standard of education and their intellectual capacity at this age. Of course, what we are doing is our level best to dissuade young people from continuing their education. That, I believe, discriminates against those people in lower socio-economic circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: It is one thing to put a child or young adult, as I have described, into that hideous situation, but that child is helped if the parents have had some form of academic training and background because the parents then will at least understand the kind of academic, social and other pressures on the child. A child from a non-academic background in Australia where we do not have equality of opportunity in education, although many people profess it, is almost inevitably a person from a lower socio-economic background. Hence we have this massive discrimination against people with intellectual capacity from those lower socio-economic backgrounds who are trying to achieve something which their parents could not achieve. Although we commend the work done by the Schools Commission, we regret the removal of Dr McKinnon, the fact that the Commission did not take up some of the questions it might have taken up and the fact that debate on this matter in the Senate has been shortened-not by deliberate government policy-and has not been encouraged to go further.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I would like to make a couple of comments about the report from the Aboriginal Land Commissioner in the Northern Territory. In the first instance, the Opposition welcomes the report and congratulates the Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey, on the very competent and sound job he is doing in this very sensitive area of hearing land claims in the Northern Territory and making recommendations to the Minister. In our view progress with regard to Aboriginal land claims in the Northern Territory has been quite satisfactory. Some claims are proceeding very slowly-I think too slowly for the satisfaction of the people involved-but we understand that there are genuine reasons for this and that in any case the slowness of the processing of some claims is in no way criticism of the competence of the Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey. We welcome Mr Justice Toohey's reappointment for another two years because we believe he has shown great sensitivity and great soundness in his conduct of these matters.

However, in the Senate this afternoon I would like to raise the concern felt by the Opposition about the attitude of the Northern Territory Government to Mr Justice Toohey and the work he has been carrying out. I have here a copy of a submission made by the Northern Territory Administration of Mr Paul Everingham and entitled 'An Examination of Land Rights Legislation-Submission by the Northern Territory Government'. There are a number of alarming features in this report. In fact it reinforces our concern that the Northern Territory Administration, the Government of Mr Paul Everingham, is fundamentally hostile to the Federal land rights Act. It is not supportive of or sympathetic to the philosophy behind the land rights Act and we believe it is prepared to undermine both the operation of the land rights Act and the work of Mr Justice Toohey. I am very pleased the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) is in the chamber to listen to these remarks.

It seems to us that the land rights movement in the Northern Territory is under some serious threat at this stage. Not only is it under threat from predatory mining companies which, of course, are anxious to assert their rights over the rights of Aboriginal people to land, but also it is under threat in a less active way from the Northern Territory Administration itself which is seeking, we believe, to persuade the Federal Government to water down the provisions of the land rights Act. Of course, it is seeking by this action and by its own participation in land rights claims to stir up within the community in the Northern Territory a great deal of hostility to the whole land rights issue. I would like to quote from this document I have before me this afternoon, which is the Northern Territory Government's submission on the land rights legislation. In particular I would like to read out paragraph 1.5 which states:

The conduct of the claims themselves by practitioners for the applicants are also a cause for concern. Fierce attempts are made by those representing various Aboriginal applicants to prevent any normal and proper cross-examination of their clients or witnesses as to the reality, or genuineness, of the claim of traditional ownership made by particular claimants. This amounts to an attempt to distort the normal legal process and to emasculate a proper consideration of other interests affected, and indeed, the interests of the community as a whole. To say the least, not infrequently, some of the claims of traditional ownership in the terms defined are specious. There is a consequent acute danger in this situation because of the markedly benevolent view taken by the Commissioner to applications taken under the Act. A strong feeling exists that the Minister should not merely rubber stamp the recommendations of the Commissioner but should carefully examine each case himself.

A statement such as that coming from the Northern Territory Government, I think, should be regarded by Aboriginal people as a very serious threat to their land rights. First of all, Mr Everingham insults the legal representatives of the Aboriginal people by suggesting that they are pursuing the claims in a way which is distorting-I use the words in the submission-the normal legal process. Secondly, he suggests that the interests of the community as a whole are being ignored by the development of the land rights claims. Then, of course, he goes on to insult and to undermine Mr Justice Toohey by speaking of his markedly benevolent view. I draw the inference that Mr Justice Toohey is making decisions which are not soundly based in law but rather are a result of his benovolence. I think that is a very serious accusation to make against a judge. Mr Everingham also suggests that the Minister is merely rubber-stamping the Commissioner's recommendations. I am sure that the Minister does not take kindly to being described in this way, even though Senator Peter Baume, the Minister at this stage, is fairly new to this portfolio and, I think, probably has accepted only one recommendation for a land rights claim.

TALK.START.PARA: —Borroloola.

—Borroloola was accepted. Perhaps it is his colleague, Senator Chaney, who should feel more outraged at these sorts of suggestions. But I raise this matter at this stage because I think it is a serious one. I think the submission-I would be quite happy to table it if the Minister requests it-demonstrates the bad faith of the Northern Territory Administration towards the development of land rights in the Northern Territory. There are other matters which I will not go into in detail because the hour is late but about which I am concerned. For example, recommendation 2.2.1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . The Northern Territory Government considers that the Commonwealth Act should be amended to prevent any further applications--
That is for land owned by or on behalf of Aboriginal people to be converted into Aboriginal land-
for such conversion being lodged.

Again, as set out in recommendation 3.2.1, the Northern Territory Government believes that immediately upon the commencement of the new amendments to the Act no new lodgment for Aboriginal land claims should be made. I think this is a submission very hostile to the interests of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. Indeed it is a submission hostile to the Federal Government and its stated policy and its performance to date in the matter of land rights claims.

I hope and expect that the Minister, Senator Peter Baume, like me, will congratulate Mr Justice Toohey on his report and for his conduct of the land rights claims. I hope that he will reject in this place the various unsympathetic or hostile suggestions by the Everingham Government, but in particular will reject the suggestion that Mr Justice Toohey is acting in a way so as to allow a distortion of the law. I hope he will reject the suggestion that the Minister is acting as a rubber stamp and perhaps should be an authority over and above the judge in this matter. It is of serious concern to members of the Federal Opposition because our commitment to land rights for Aboriginal people is unqualified. For this reason we have supported the legislation of the Federal Government in the Northern Territory, but we constantly monitor the threats to Aboriginal land rights in the Northern Territory. I believe that the submission of the Everingham Government to which I have referred this afternoon constitutes such a threat. I seek leave to table this document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now table this document and conclude my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I wish to make it quite clear that the work of Mr Justice Toohey is work for which the Government has the greatest admiration-the way in which he initiated and conducted the hearings of these claims and the way in which he continues to do his duties. I wish to make it quite clear that at the Federal Government level we have nothing but praise for the way in which he does this job.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan has drawn attention to a document written by the Northern Territory Government. In fact she tabled the document. I think the honourable senator would want to know that the document is a little out of date at this stage; that there has been some progress. I was able to convene a meeting in Darwin the day before the ministerial council, a meeting consisting of representatives of the Federal Government, of the Northern Territory Government and of the three land councils in the Northern Territory. Those representatives met around the same table to discuss the question of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and to try to reach a number of agreed positions. The honourable senator is quite correct; that document existed but I must say to her that the views which emerged from that meeting were far more positive and far more conciliatory on all sides, and it would be my hope that in due course we will end up with a series of agreed positions on a number of matters relating to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. That is a development which should be put before the Senate at this stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: -Last Thursday I sought leave to continue my remarks on the first reading of these Bills. At that stage I had confined my remarks to the problem abroad at present in regard to salinity in the River Murray, and I had dealt at length with the problems that exist. At page 829 of the Senate Hansard of 26 March I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am reliably informed that New South Wales is well ahead of the other States in getting money from the fund to control salinity in that State.

I was referring to the legislation passed in this House three years ago which provided the sum of $200m for water resources. On checking that information I found that I was somewhat incorrect and should not have said that New South Wales was well ahead in getting money from the fund but that New South Wales was ahead in requesting money for water resources. I was able to ascertain that information in discussions I had with people in New South Wales, and I want to correct that slight error. Let me now recapitulate on some of the things I said last Thursday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Indirectly, you were not entirely wrong because so much money has been spent on water conservation in those States that they are ahead of South Australia.

—They are well ahead of South Australia, I know, but they would be much further ahead if they could get more money from the fund. Even though they have started some of the works, they find great difficulty in getting money allocated. As I said last Thursday when I quoted from an answer given to Mr Jacobi in the other place, although the scheme has been in operation for at least three years, less than $77m has been forthcoming out of a total amount of $200m. With less than two years to go there is still $123m in the fund. Yet New South Wales is being severely criticised by the South Australian Minister for something he says it is doing and which I am convinced it is not doing; that is, putting more salt into the River Murray system. If New South Wales could get access to that money, I am sure it could go ahead more rapidly with the works it has in progress. Of course, I see some difficulties in altering the Constitution to force any State to carry out salinity control within its own borders. I mention those things now becasuse I think they ought to be placed on the record, in view of the answers given last week in this chamber by Senator Carrick.

SPEECH.PARA: On 3 March, when speaking to the tabling of the Australian Water Resources Council report, I stated:
If Mr Arnold continues to carry on in the way in which he has been carrying on, . . . he could put the whole agreement in jeopardy.

I was referring to the amendments to the River Murray Waters Agreement. I said two years ago, and even as far back as 1976 when I spoke on the legislation that made the $200m available, that we had to have a consensus of all the States if we were to improve the quality of the River Murray water. On 5 March, in answer to a question from me about the River Murray, Senator Carrick said:

South Australia, in arriving at its estimate of 28 per cent of salt in the River Murray being contributed by New South Wales, has updated the Maunsell analysis on the basis of available information on river flows during the period October to December 1980.

South Australia has based its opinion that New South Wales has an input of 28 per cent of salt into the River Murray on a very short period of two months. I believe it should have based its assessment on a much longer period, and to my mind that figure of 28 per cent is in serious question. Again on 5 March, when I spoke in the Senate about the problems experienced in the River Murray being expanded most unfairly by Mr Arnold, the Minister of Water Resources in South Australia, I said:

I would have thought that the Minister who lives in that area and represents those people would have informed them that public protests will not assist in any way to secure satisfactory amendments to the River Murray Waters Agreement.

I was talking about a letter I had received and quoted in my speech in the Address-in-Reply debate, and I said that public protests would not achieve anything. In a series of answers, Senator Carrick has borne out what I said. On 24 March, in answer to a question on the River Murray from Senator Davidson, Senator Carrick said:

The States and the Commonwealth are currently in full discussion to obtain a complete redrafting of an agreement on the River Murray. There are now only two matters in dispute. We are endeavouring to hasten their resolution.
He went on:
. . . but in a federation what is required in terms of progress is a consensus.
That is what I have been saying here for a number of years. Talking about the Maunsell report, Senator Carrick went on:
I am aware of the Maunsell report. All these things are under study.
He was referring to the matters raised by Senator Davidson, but I will not repeat them because they are set out in Hansard. Senator Carrick continued:
We intend to act upon them.

He was referring to the recommendations in the Maunsell report. I wish only that Senator Carrick would do what he said he intended to do, and that is act upon the recommendations in the 1979 Maunsell report entitled 'Murray Valley Salinity and Drainage Report'. That report recommended an expenditure of $75.24m to correct salinity in the River Murray. As I said a while ago in answer to an interjection from Senator Young, we now find that New South Wales, which is doing its utmost, is having great difficulty in getting a share of the $200m that was made available for this very purpose. Yet Senator Carrick is on record as saying only last week that the Government of which he is the responsible Minister intends to act upon the Maunsell report. I believe that the Federal Government should take immediate action to make the necessary funds available to each of the States to enable these recommendations to be implemented without delay. Of course, if the Government were prepared to do that, the States might not now be engaged in this dispute. It is most regrettable because the more Mr Arnold and Mr Tonkin criticise the New South Wales Government the longer it will be before a conclusion is reached. As Senator Carrick has said, a conclusion has almost been reached and only one or two points embodied in the suggested amendments need clarification. If only those two people in South Australia would close their mouths for a little while we might get somewhere. Again on 24 March Senator Bishop put a question to the Minister, and in reply Senator Carrick said:

As Senator Bishop knows, this is a Federal-State matter. The degree to which any kind of agreement can be reached depends upon the good will and the unanimity of views of some four partners in this venture. The aim at this moment is to get the maximum co-operation we can within a re-writing of the River Murray Commission agreement and from there to see whether any further steps are necessary.
He went on:
That will be a primary target on our part.

I only wish it were a primary target on the part of Mr Arnold and Mr Tonkin from South Australia. A further question was asked by Senator Young on that day, and in reply Senator Carrick talked again about the States. He said:

. . . within their sovereign territories higher up the river system. That is where the nub of the problem lies; they have total sovereignty. Unless we get voluntary co-operation, the journey will be so much the harder.
He went on further:
It is a question of a federation and State sovereignty. It is true that we need unanimity of support.

Everywhere we look we find the Minister responsible using those words. On 24 March, in answer to a question from Senator Teague about the Government's seeking to bring about a moratorium on irrigation, Senator Carrick said:
. . . I do not think any Commonwealth government could intervene at the State level on what are solely sovereign powers.

So there we have it. We know what the Constitution is, and yet people from South Australia, both in the Senate and from bodies along the River Murray, continually complain and criticise the New South Wales Government, saying that it is that Government's responsibility to give South Australia better quality water. It is no such thing because under the Constitution, as has been clearly stated both in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources and in answers given by Senator Carrick, each State has sovereignty over its own water resources. If we want to try to come to some agreement under which a State gives away something for which it could be severely criticised by its own residents, we have to do it in a proper manner. We should not get up on a soap box and shout our heads off and fool people, as Mr Arnold is doing, as I have pointed out recently.

As I have said in other speeches I have made, Mr Dunstan and Mr Corcoran, who was the South Australian Minister of Works, as the portfolio then was, could have done the same thing to Mr Askin and to Mr Lewis. They could have made some cheap political propaganda, but they are old hands at the game; they are politically wise. They knew that as the Constitution stands they would not get anywhere by criticising, so they sat down to talk in a rational manner with the Premiers of both New South Wales and Victoria. Both States had Liberal Premiers at that time, and Victoria still does. As I have said, it is remarkable that no criticism has been levelled at Mr Hamer either by Mr Tonkin or Mr Arnold for the amount of salt that Victoria might be contributing to the River Murray. All the criticism seems to be levelled at a Labor government. There is no doubt in my mind that they are using this issue for political purposes as an election is to be held in New South Wales shortly. They think they will be able to gain some political kudos from it. But I can assure them that they will not do so. All they are doing is building up false hopes for the people along the River Murray in South Australia.

I understand that a meeting was held yesterday at Waikerie. A committee of 18 people was formed and I am informed that the committee hopes to raise about $50,000. I have not seen any reports in the Press on this matter. No doubt it will be reported in the South Australian Press tomorrow. But these people will not achieve anything. As I have said on many occasions-my colleague Senator McClelland will back me up on this-if we want to get South Australia a better deal we had better be prepared to sit down and talk in a conciliatory manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —New South Wales is undertaking a $15m program of works which will further reduce input of salt by New South Wales into the Murray.

—Yes, I am aware of that. I am pleased that Senator McClelland has raised it because it brings me back to what I said a few minutes ago, that is, that New South Wales is experiencing some difficulty in getting from the Federal Government more of that $200m provided in the legislation we passed. If New South Wales could get money it would help it to complete the works that it is already carrying out. As members of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources Senator Thomas, who is in the chamber, and I had the experience of going into the Wakool, Deniliquin and Wentworth areas on the New South Wales side of the river near Mildura and seeing the work that was being done to try to control salinity. I was convinced then that the landholders in that part of New South Wales had a problem and that the Government was doing everything it could to try to correct it.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to criticise other States for what they are doing under their sovereign rights even though I live in South Australia. My main concern is to see that South Australia gets better quality water. As I have said in this place on many occasions, I am very much afraid that if the present South Australian Government continues to carry on as it has been doing we will not get anywhere in our efforts to get the River Murray Waters Agreement amended. This is what the Government should bear in mind instead of trying to score cheap political points. I was convinced that Mr Arnold had seen the error of his ways, was prepared to sit down and discuss these matters and not to go public further. But unfortunately for him his leader, Mr Tonkin, went on air on the Australian Broadcasting Commission's 7 o'clock news on Channel 2 on 16 March. I have a transcript of what he had to say. The newsreader said:
The Premier, Mr Tonkin, today called on NSW to honour its responsibilities to South Australia over the quality of River Murray water.
According to the transcript of the news item Mr Tonkin said:

Now, it seems to me that the NSW Government is acting totally without any conscience at all in this matter and if our approach to the NSW Government doesn't succeed, then I hope that the people of NSW will recognise their responsibilities to fellow Australians in South Australia and call on the NSW Government to act responsibly.

Those statements made by the Premier are completely provocative because he is talking about New South Wales honouring its responsibilities in relation to water quality. No State has responsibility to another State in relation to water quality. That is not mentioned in the Agreement. I shall refer to the extra amount of water which South Australia received under the Dartmouth agreement; there is no mention of quality in that agreement, only quantity. I will refer to that matter later too, because South Australia is doing very well as far as its allocation of water is concerned. I saw in the Weekend Australian a report headed 'States rights go on the rampage'. It was making reference to a meeting of the Federal Liberal Party. I will not quote all of it but one small part of it attracted my attention. It reads:
This growing 'states rightism' surfaced again in the party room last Wednesday, when the South Australians, led by former Premier Steele Hall, forced on a debate on the pollution of the River Murray.

I cannot verify whether that statement is correct. Only the people who were in the party room know whether that is in fact correct. What we have to bear in mind is that when Mr Steele Hall as Premier of South Australia negotiated the extra water entitlement from the Dartmouth dam-he is a signatory to that agreement-nothing was said in the agreement about water quality. On Thursday he asked of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in the other place a question about water quality and pollution in the River Murray. He well knows he had the opportunity during the negotiations on the construction of the Dartmouth dam to do something about water quality. He could have insisted upon his proposals. The other States might not have agreed with them but at least he could have done something about the problem.

I have a copy of that agreement which is signed by Mr Steele Hall. The people who signed it include Mr Gorton who was then the Prime Minister, Mr Askin who was the then Premier of New South Wales, Mr Bolte the then Premier of Victoria and Mr Steele Hall, the then Premier of South Australia. All of those people are signatories to the Dartmouth agreement. All that we of South Australia got out of it was an entitlement to extra water; there was nothing in it about quality of water.
