Now that Mr Hall is in the House of Representatives he is prepared to say in his party room-this is what is reported and I have not heard anyone on the other side of the chamber deny it-that we ought to do something to safeguard water quality for South Australia. I am asking: Why did he not do that when he was the Premier and he had the opportunity when the agreement to construct the Dartmouth dam was being negotiated?

TALK.START.PARA: —They were all Liberals then, too, weren't they?

—They were all Liberals. They cannot blame a Labor Government in any State because we had Liberal governments in every State and at the Commonwealth level. But nothing was said. Mr Hall, as Premier of South Australia, has a very sorry record on water issues. Many years ago when Mr Playford was negotiating the agreement to construct the Chowilla dam and Steele Hall became Premier-I think it was in 1964-he was very concerned, so concerned that he put out a pamphlet headed 'The Fourteen Facts About Chowilla'. It sets out the reasons the dam should be built and why it was a good thing. He made great play of it, but then he changed his mind for some reason best known to himself. Of course this brought about his downfall. I even heard him saying at one time that Chowilla would be built even if he had to dig it himself so that South Australia could have an assured water supply. But for some reason or other he changed his mind and supported the construction of Dartmouth. He is on record as saying recently-he was trying to blame the Dunstan Government-that the Dartmouth agreement was held up for two years by Mr Dunstan; no such thing occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: Having put those matters on the record, I want to say something-I will be brief because one of my colleagues wants to speak before the dinner break-about the River Murray system as we know it and its whole history. The State of New South Wales-I am convinced about this-has followed a consistent course of support for the equitable sharing of the water resources of the River Murray, for the improvement of water quality and for the widening of the present limited powers of the River Murray Commission. New South Wales has always supported that. We are very near the point where we can get some agreement, where South Australia might get a better deal. Yet, Mr Arnold-as I said before-did not see fit to make any submission to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources when it held a public inquiry into Australia's water resources. He made no submission then when he was a back bencher in the South Australian Opposition, the member for Chaffey and living on the river. He never saw fit to raise his voice or put in a submission to let us hear of all the problems. We never heard from him.

New South Wales claims-I believe it-it has pioneered salinity mitigation projects to reduce the amount of salt entering the river and has effective systems either in use or under construction at present. Those projects at present under construction are the ones I have mentioned as being delayed because the New South Wales Government cannot get sufficient money from the Federal Government. It has progressively stopped taking applications for new irrigation licences along regulated inland rivers since 1977 despite the fact that it is being publicised now that it is issuing licences willy-nilly for the Darling. My information-I have no reason to doubt it-is that no licences have been granted since 1977. It is perfectly understandable that the people of South Australia, so heavily dependent on the Murray, should be concerned about water quality and the assurance of future supplies for domestic, agricultural and industrial use. The Government of New South Wales finds it very difficult to understand why it has been subjected to an increasing barrage of criticism from the South Australian Government.

I have stood in this chamber repeatedly to speak about the criticism levelled at New South Wales by certain representatives of that State in the Federal Parliament and interested parties in the Riverland district of South Australia. I have referred to those often. We should not have to keep defending New South Wales; it is quite capable of defending itself. Again, the main purpose for my rising in this place is to get some sense into Mr Tonkin and Mr Arnold and to ask them to sit down to talk with representatives from the other two States to see whether we can reach an agreement satisfactory to everyone. The general tone of the criticism levelled is that in this regard all the problems of the quality of Murray River water effectively relate to salt content and are due to the New South Wales Government and the farmers of that State. This is unfair, inaccurate and unjust. My New South Wales Senate colleagues would back me on that statement. Furthermore, the main thrust of the campaign appears to be endeavouring to secure the flow of as much water as possible along the River Murray in South Australia to flush the salt concentration into the sea. It is implied but not spelled out in detail that the flushing involving vast quantities of water should be at the expense of water users in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wastage!

—It is absolute wastage just to go out through the barrages into the sea. In the late 1979 South Australia took the unprecedented step of sending representatives to appear at two New South Wales land board hearings held to inquire into the desirability of granting individual irrigation licences along the Darling River. The decision of one of these at Wentworth is currently the subject of an appeal before Mr Justice Perrignon of the Land and Environment Court. The South Australian campaign, as I said, has been conducted by Mr Arnold. He is objecting personally to the issuance of 150 licences along the Darling or its tributaries upstream from the Menindee Lakes storage. Mr Arnold claims the granting of such licences would accentuate the salinity problem of the Murray. Why has Mr Arnold taken out a challenge in the New South Wales courts? This is very interesting. I will tell honourable senators why. South Australia is challenging licences granted in New South Wales because in Victoria, a far greater contributor than New South Wales to the salt problem of the Murray, no provision exists for appeals against the issuance of irrigation licences. In Queensland, where the Darling and some of its tributaries rise, the right of appeal against the issuance of an irrigation licence is restricted to people in the immediate vicinity of the licence application area. In both Victoria and Queensland there is no right of appeal. There is no right of appeal in Victoria. In Queensland, unless one is adjacent to the river, one has no right of appeal.
—That's fair enough.

—Of course it is fair enough, but in South Australia what are we doing? What is the South Australian Minister doing? He is taking court action in New South Wales against a State government. What a hide he has. If Senator MacGibbon agrees with what happens in regard to the law in Queensland then he must agree that Mr Arnold is completely wrong in going to New South Wales.
—Are you saying that extra land developed on the Darling will not increase the salinity in South Australia?

—I am saying that. We have evidence to prove that it will not. Clearly, New South Wales is the target State in the South Australian campaign to increase the flow of water along the Murray to dilute the salt content of the Murray. This means that a resource taken away from New South Wales users becomes merely dilution water to be wasted and flushed out to sea through the barrages at Goolwa. I repeat: I have had evidence given to me-I have no cause to doubt it-that any extra irrigation licences granted on the Darling, if they are granted, will not have any effect on the River Murray. This is because certain conditions have been laid down. I have spoken of these.

SPEECH.PARA: In criticising Mr Arnold I am backed up by the statements of Mr Keneally, the member for Stuart in South Australia. He is the South Australian spokesman on water resources and is convinced that Mr Arnold is only playing politics. An article appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser on about the same date that Mr Tonkin issued his ultimatum to Mr Wran. I am not going to quote from that article because time is running out and my colleague wishes to speak before 6 o'clock. As I have said, New South Wales is not accepting applications for licences for further irrigation development along the Murray and its regulated tributaries. This is because the Australian Water Resources Council considers that regulated flows capable of being developed in normal non-drought years are fully committed for domestic and stock use, to support permanent plantings and for irrigation generally.

Mr Corcoran himself when Minister made statements which are on record. I have a Press release of his which I might use if we ever have a full-scale debate on the River Murray, which I am sure eventually we will. Mr Corcoran granted an extra ten per cent of licences to people along the River Murray in South Australia because South Australia was getting far in excess of its water entitlement. We do in most years; it is very seldom that we do not get the entitlement. It was only once that South Australia did not get its entitlement. That was in a time of drought and neither Victoria nor New South Wales at that time had their entitlement either. In every other year South Australia gets in excess of its entitlement under the agreement. The Premier of South Australia is continually harping and trying to blame a sister State for causing the problem. As I have said, we will not get anywhere if South Australia continues to do that. I only hope that the time will come when we have a full-scale debate in this Parliament on the River Murray instead of dealing with it in a piecemeal way as I have done this afternoon on the first reading of a money Bill when one cannot devote the full time necessary to it.

Mr Arnold has two colleagues sitting in this chamber-Senator Young and Senator Messner -who, if they are as concerned as I and my colleagues from South Australia on this side of the chamber are that there should be better quality water in South Australia, for goodness sake should explain to the Minister. The honourable senators do not need to quote me but can quote their own leader, Senator Carrick, who has said repeatedly in the last week that each State has sovereign right over its own water resources. The only way to alter that would be to have a federal referendum. Honourable senators know what chances there would be of getting such a vote through. There would be as much chance of carrying that as a referendum to abolish the Senate because only one State is needed to object to negate the question. Tasmania would never vote to abolish the Senate because it would lose ten senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be done by the River Murray Commission.

—It could not be. This is stated in the constitution quoted from so often. It is stated in the report of the committee of which Senator Thomas was chairman. It is not possible to give those powers to the River Murray Commission.
—I am not saying the sovereign rights.
—Those powers cannot be handed away.
—Water quality could be in the--

—Better water quality can be achieved if the States are prepared to talk in a rational manner. As I have said on so many occasions, in order to have better quality water in South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales will have to give something to us but they will get nothing in return. It is disturbing to me that in the interview I mentioned with Mr Tonkin, the interviewer asked whether the sort of reprisal being considered by Mr Tonkin concerned the cutting off of natural gas from the Moomba field to New South Wales. Of course, Mr Tonkin said that he was not considering that. However, there must have been some discussion of that or the interviewer would not have raised the subject. Engaging in reprisals such as that will not get anywhere while each State has its sovereign right. Again I make the plea to you, Mr President, to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, and to Senator Young that when you go back to South Australia you point these matters out to Mr Arnold and repeat what Senator Carrick said-not what I have said-that each State has its sovereign rights. He said repeatedly here last week that the only way we will get better quality water in South Australia is for all the Ministers and all the State governments to sit down in harmony and discuss the problems with the Federal Government. We will not get anywhere while we have this antagonistic attitude adopted by the South Australian Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -I want to speak briefly on two matters. The first concerns a question that I asked in the Senate on 5 December last year. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: My question to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, who is representing the Prime Minister in this place, refers to a statement made in the House of Representatives on 6 June last year--
That is 1979-

in which the present Minister for Communications acknowledged that several hundred thousand dollars misappropriated by G. M. Sinclair had been paid into the account of the Sinclair Pastoral Co. and that by a deed of arrangement dated 1 August 1979 the Minister agreed to repay $300,000 commencing on 1 November 1980. Will the Deputy Leader of the Government ask the Prime Minister whether public documents reveal that up to 1 November this year a family company of the Minister for Communications was the custodian and beneficiary of 300,000 misappropriated dollars and whether the Prime Minister approves of the use of misappropriated funds as working capital for private ministerial businesses? If the Prime Minister does not so approve, why did he reappoint Mr Sinclair to the Cabinet?

That was the end of my question. Senator Durack replied that he would refer the question to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). As no reply was received by 3 March this year, I raised the matter again at Question Time. On 3 March the Deputy President, who is a member of Mr Sinclair's party, demanded that I withdraw the question which was accepted on 5 December. When I did not I was ultimately suspended. However, on 10 March I received what purported to be a reply to my 5 December question. In that reply Senator Durack, on behalf of the Prime Minister, said:

The Prime Minister has advised that the affairs of the companies you referred to, together with other companies, were investigated under the New South Wales Companies Act. Mr Sinclair was acquitted by the jury on all charges laid as a result of this investigation.
As a result, the Prime Minister regards the issue as being closed.

It ought to be obvious, even to the recipient of a third-class Oxford degree, that that reply had nothing to do with my question. Senator Durack's letter on behalf of the Prime Minister referred to the fact that a jury in Sydney, after a seven-hour deliberation, found Mr Sinclair not guilty of three charges of forgery, three charges of uttering and three charges of breaching the New South Wales Companies Act. The letter referred to nothing else. On the other hand my question referred to Mr Sinclair's speech in Parliament on 6 June 1979. In that speech he quoted from a letter written by G. Sinclair, Haylen and Co., accountants, to the directors of Reliance Investments Pty Ltd. The letter stated inter alia:
(1) The following funds were misappropriated by the late Mr G. Sinclair.

The Sinclair, Haylen and Co. letter, as quoted by the Minister on 6 June, then listed misappropriations totalling $542,125.05 and the four accounts into which the funds were paid. The greater part of the money, $377,000, was shown as paid to the Sinclair Pastoral Co. Pty Ltd. Ian Sinclair is and was the principal of that company. Mr Sinclair, later in his 6 June speech, quoted from his letter to the Reliance group on 11 April 1979 in which he stated:
I accept responsibility for the repayment of this amount as trustee of the estate of the late George Sinclair. Repayment will be in accordance with arrangements to be determined with the company.

A deed of arrangement dated 1 August 1979 was subsequently released by Mr Ian Sinclair in which he agreed to pay $430,000 to the Reliance group. Claims for $130,000 of accountants fees due to George Sinclair were forgone, and $130,000 was deemed to have been paid off the $430,000. Of the remaining $300,000 Ian Sinclair undertook to repay $100,000 on 1 November 1980 and the other $200,000 in the next two years. That is all in the deed of arrangement which was released on 2 August, I think, by Mr Sinclair. As well as being the principal of the Sinclair Pastoral Co., Ian Sinclair was the sole beneficiary of his father's estate and therefore, until such time as those funds are repaid, the custodian of funds which he has acknowledged were misappropriated by George Sinclair. The deed of arrangement released by Ian Sinclair-under his ministerial letterhead-in August 1979 reveals that he was still in possession of 300,000 of the misappropriated dollars when the Prime Minister reappointed him to Cabinet in August 1980, and that he still retains $200,000.

From documents and statements from Ian Sinclair, it is inarguable that he was the custodian and user of misappropriated funds when the Prime Minister reappointed him to Cabinet. From that it is logically inescapable that the Prime Minister has no objection to the use of misappropriated money as working capital for ministerial businesses. My question of 5 December sought only the Prime Minister's confirmation of that logical conclusion. His answer dodged the issue. If Ian Sinclair had been acquitted of every charge from illegal parking to wilful murder, it would neither challenge nor change the public record which shows that he was still in possession of 300,000 misappropriated dollars when Mr Fraser elevated him to senior Cabinet rank. Even a third-class Oxford graduate ought to be able to deduce that. The Prime Minister's restoration of the member for New England is just one of the multiple examples of his craven subservience to the National Country Party; his evasion of the question is an example of his arrogant disdain for parliament.

For the last week or so-this is the second matter-we have been subjected to a plague of cant and humbug from senior Ministers. With a public record like that of Sir Phillip Lynch, it takes a very thick hide to accuse anyone of making demands, as he has done twice in the last nine days, based on, as he put it, greed not need. This comes from a man who has a huge ministerial salary and an assured lifelong fat ministerial pension who simultaneously ripped off huge profits from insider trading at Stumpy Gully, and then contrived to dodge tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Are you saying that the Minister personally ripped off?
—His family company in which he was the major shareholder.
—Are you referring to his family company, not the person?
—Mr President, if you would like it put that way I am quite happy to make that change of wording.
—You cannot impute to any individual member of parliament that sort of insinuation.

—It is a matter of public record-admitted even by Sir Phillip Lynch, but only after it had been previously disclosed in the Victorian Parliament-that the family company, of which he is the governing director, made huge profits from insider trading on land at Stumpy Gully and then contrived an arrangement to minimise the tax on those anti-social, to say the least, gains. Were actions like that motivated by greed or by need? Does the report on these matters, the publication of which was promised but not delivered by both Mr Fraser and Sir Phillip Lynch, answer that question? Moreover, Sir Phillip Lynch, as Treasurer in July 1977, obtained a very soft loan for $79,000 from QBE Insurance Ltd, a company for which just six months earlier he as Treasurer had approved a foreign investment transaction. Leaving aside the propriety of the transaction, was the Lynch family so destitute that it really needed the capital gains from that Gold Coast apartment? According to Sir Phillip Lynch at the time, the loan was a normal commercial transaction-an assertion inadvertently scuttled by the QBE manager's public statement that loans were never granted for residential property, never granted for amounts of less than $100,000 and never granted for more than five years. The Lynch soft loan breached all of those conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: The humbug has since been compounded by the Prime Minister himself. The Prime Minister, the principal of a proprietary company, Fraser Properties, the purpose of which is to avoid or minimise taxation, had the temerity to condemn-I use his words-anti-social tax avoidance schemes which are so abhorrent to the Australian community.

On the question of taxation on a broader scale, the Government's proudest boast is the abolition of inheritance taxes, which were paid by only a small, relatively privileged minority. If any group has succumbed to greed it is only following the example set in such grand style by the Government in general and by the Prime Minister and Mr Lynch, or Sir Phillip Lynch, in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a personal reflection on the Prime Minister and Sir Phillip Lynch.
—And the Governor- General.
—He did not say the 'Governor-General'; he said the 'Government'.
—I did not mean to mention the Governor-General. If I did, I am sorry.
—Personal reflections-that was a highly personal reflection-cannot be permitted.
—I presume you are asking me to withdraw them, Mr President. I will withdraw them.
—I am asking you to withdraw them.
—I will withdraw. It is a matter of public record, however, that Mr Lynch--
—I am not asking you to debate the matter. I am demanding that you withdraw.

—I have withdrawn, Mr President. I am continuing my speech. It is a matter of public record that Mr Lynch's family company, following advice fortuitously received from his friend and one-time campaign manager, Peter Leake, who was a member of a planning authority in Victoria governing land zoning regulations, that land at Stumpy Gully was about to be rezoned for subdivision, acquired some of that land, which after the re-zoning was subsequently sold at a very substantial profit-from memory, $79,000. Arrangements were also made to minimise the taxation on that gain. It is also a matter of public record, and has been for some years, that the Prime Minister's own business is conducted under a proprietary company called Fraser Properties, set up for the same reason. This inconsistency in consistent--

—Order! I am listening very closely to what you are saying. You are saying that certain things are done for a certain purpose. You have no authority to say that. You would not know, as I would not know, in what manner a member of parliament attends to his business matters. You are making insinuations which are highly disorderly.
—Mr President, with due respect, I reckon that even a member of the National Country Party or a third class Oxford graduate would be able to work out why those arrangements were made.

—Inherent in what you are saying is an imputation of improper motive. You have no grounds on which to impute an improper motive unless you know precisely why a person has done certain things. You are drawing inferences in a way which is not in the best interests of the respect we must show to one another as members in this place.
—Mr President, if it is improper to make arrangements to minimise taxation, that is a value judgment which I have not made. The Prime Minister, though, apparently thinks that it is improper because--

—I was referring to an insinuation which was inherent in what you were saying. I ask you to continue. I shall be listening very closely to you. If you trespass any further at all in respect of personal reflections, which I think are inherent but which I cannot prove at this moment, I will not hesitate to use the sanctions of the Standing Orders.

—Yes, Mr President. The Prime Minister, apparently, judging from his statement, which I will quote again shortly, does think that it is improper to make those sorts of arrangements. He referred to anti-social tax avoidance schemes which are so abhorrent to the Australian community. There seems to be some inconsistency between that belief, proclaimed last week, which I have just quoted, and matters shown by the public record. With the exception of Andrew Peacock, I cannot think of anyone other than Mr Fraser and Mr Lynch who would have had the effrontery as Minister for the Army to dispatch conscripts to Vietnam while himself being of prime military age. Certainly, no previous politician would have had the nerve to try it, let alone gotten away with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -For some time I have had an interest in whether an allowance can be provided for blind pensioners who have a guide dog. My initial interest in this matter was aroused when an old blind friend contacted me and told me that in order to allow her dog to eat she had to skip meals on various occasions. This blind friend has since passed away but it seems to me that the problem that she faced is still being faced by many blind people who have a guide dog and who have only the pension that is provided to them by the Government to live on. At the moment the single pension is about $60 a week. Out of this pension a number of pensioners who have a guide dog have to care for their dog as well as for themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Guide dogs, of course, are of tremendous importance to blind people. They give them mobility and a certain amount of independence that they would not otherwise have. I have contacted the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) on this matter on a number of occasions to see whether an allowance can be granted to these people. I want to see that those who are on the basic blind pension receive some allowance to help them with the care of their dog. Unfortunately on each occasion that I have contacted the Minister he has missed the real point that I have been trying to make. What he has said in answer each time is that there is no real need to provide an allowance for people who have a guide dog because the blind receive a pension which is free of income test. The implication there is that because the pension is free of income test blind persons can receive it in addition to having an income; therefore they are receiving some consideration already and should not be paid an extra allowance for their guide dog. The Minister is really missing the point altogether. A number of blind people receive only the basic pension. A number of single people in this situation are finding it extremely difficult not only to keep themselves but also to keep their dog.

I contacted a guide dog association to ask what it would cost to keep a guide dog. The person to whom I spoke could not answer me exactly but told me that it would cost at least $10 a week, stressing the words 'at least'. One must take into account not only the food that the dog requires but also other costs. The dog needs to have a special shampoo if it is to be taken on public transport with the owner. It needs brushes and it needs coats. There are all sorts of incidental expenses in addition to the food that it needs. I have been told that all this would cost at least $10 a week. If one takes $10 a week from a pension of about $60 a week the pensioner is getting far less than the poverty level, far less than we really believe that single pensioners should have.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was outlining how I believed that blind pensioners who have a guide dog should receive an allowance. I mentioned that the guide dog costs a considerable amount for the blind person to keep. I also outlined how the single blind pensioner who has to rely solely on a pension probably receives only about $60 a week. In fact, the pension for a blind person is $64.10 a week. I also outlined how it costs at least $10 a week for a blind person to keep a guide dog. There are not only food costs involved but also other costs. I said that I had approached the Minister for Social Security on a number of occasions suggesting the allowance but that on each occasion either the Minister had misunderstood my remarks or his Department had and suggested that because the blind person receives an income test free pension he should be able to afford to keep his guide dog.

SPEECH.PARA: I recently asked the Minister for Social Security a question to find out what it would cost the Government to provide, say, a $10 a week allowance for people who have guide dogs. This was my question:

What would be the annual cost to the Government of providing all blind pensioners who have a guide dog with an allowance of $10 a week to compensate the pensioner for expenses incurred in caring for the dog?
The answer I received contained some interesting information, but again, part of the point of the question was lost. The answer read, in part:
There are currently almost 400 working guide dogs throughout Australia. On this basis, the cost of providing an allowance of $10 a week would be just over $200,000 per year.

It seems to me that that $200,000 a year would be well worth while for the people in Australia who have guide dogs. As I will point out later, it probably would not cost a total of $200,000 a year if we were able to institute a scheme which takes need into account. The answer goes on:

I have already indicated in response to the honourable senator's Question 154 (Hansard, 5 December 1980, page 498) that although blind persons do not receive a benefit specifically for the care of a guide dog, Invalid Pension (Blind) is free of income test and this assists in offsetting the costs of maintaining a guide dog.

That is fine for those people who do have an income in addition to their invalid pension or what is often called a blind pension. Those who do have an income certainly do not have that income counted against their pension and therefore they are able to keep their dogs. But it does not do anything for the person who has the pension only. The person who has a pension only is not really interested that that pension is free of income test because he has to use that pension for himself and his dog. If that person is a single pensioner receiving only $64.10 a week and he has to take out extra for keeping his dog he will have a hard struggle because he is really keeping himself and a dog which will cost a fair amount each week to keep on that $64.10. The fact that the pension is income test free does not help him at all. The answer that the Minister gave me to my question went on to note that the Minister's Department was directly responsible for funding 25 per cent to 30 per cent of the current output of trained guide dogs through the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service. It is, of course, admirable that the Department does this but one would think that once the guide dogs are trained the Department would help the persons who are going to use them so that they can use the dogs fully and have the fuller life they were expecting when they trained their dogs and used their dogs to guide them around.

Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I also outlined how this matter was brought to my attention by a blind friend of mine who is no longer with us. She outlined to me the difficulties that she was having. She was on the single rate pension only. She had a guide dog and she was extremely mobile with it. She used to go to many places in Brisbane, unaccompanied, but for her dog. She pointed out to me that so that she could keep her dog and keep it well she had to skip meals occasionally because she just could not afford the meals for herself plus the upkeep of the dog. We should not be asking blind persons to put themselves in that situation. I am not sure whether that spartan existence she had to follow contributed to her death but I could see that it is possible when blind pensioners are placed in that position. If we do not want to commit ourselves to $200,000 a year to provide $10 a week for every person in Australia who has a guide dog, perhaps we can look at some income test whereby we pay an allowance to those who are in real need. If a person is in full time employment-and some blind persons are-and he has his blind pension as well as his normal income, perhaps there may be a case for our not providing an allowance to him. So perhaps we should have a look at some type of income test which would make sure that the blind persons who are really in need do get this type of assistance. I request the Government to consider seriously a proposal like that and if we could give it favourable consideration, as I hope the Government would be able to do in time, it would certainly be a compassionate act which we could provide for the handicapped in this, the International Year of Disabled Persons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the first reading of these Bills to say something about government expenditure in one area of government initiative, that of advertising. I want to talk about three ways in which governments or political parties use advertising. I begin by talking about the conventional way with which we are all familiar-conventional advertisements on television, radio, and in the Press at election time. Only last week there was a matter of public importance in the Senate in which this issue was raised by Senator Chipp. Allegations were made as to how the Liberals and the National Party in Western Australia in particular, had abused the process of political advertising at election times. Both Senator Gietzelt and Senator Chipp spoke about that issue. It is my view that at some stage the Parliament has to do something, in the interests of a viable democracy, about the question of the nature of political advertising and the amounts which can be spent on it. That can be done in a number of ways, either by a limitation on the television time which is available to political parties, or a limitation on radio time because it is unarguable that the conservative parties outspend the Labor Party, for example, by two to three times in every election. It is not just a matter of equity, of course; it is a matter of what the public can stand and what it is entitled to expect and to receive in terms of political propaganda of one kind or another at election times.

SPEECH.PARA: The second form of advertising to which I refer is that used by journalists who are employed on a regular basis and who are paid out of the public purse in the normal course of events. All governments use Press secretaries as a legitimate way of ensuring that the public has access to a Minister and that requests made by putative members of the public for information are met as speedily as possible. Those sorts of requests and questions should be answered by any Minister in any government as promptly as possible as part of the normal process of communicating a government's activities. In addition to what happens in the national capital of Canberra some State governments-for example, those in Queensland and Western Australia-have large propaganda units, if I can use the word 'propaganda' in this context, attached to the offices of the respective Premiers. These offices are very influential in communicating information in some cases and propaganda in others to the electorate at large.

A few days ago I asked the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, a question about the activities of the Government Information Unit in Canberra. The way in which the Minister responded to that question was very interesting. He said: 'Well, the activities of the Government Information Unit in Canberra are not really something for you to ask about because when the Whitlam Government was in power it did it too'. That is an extraordinary sort of alibi in answer to a legitimate question about the use of taxpayers' money on what is, in fact, a propaganda outfit. Senator Chaney also said: 'Look at the situation in New South Wales. There is a Labor government in New South Wales. It does that too'. One could say: Look at the situation in Senator Chaney's home State where the Premier of Western Australia has 20 Press secretaries, one for each of his 15 Ministers and five for himself. Presiding over this little empire in Western Australia is Mr John Leggoe, the former State director of the Liberal Party in Queensland, who left Queensland to become a consultant with International Public Relations Pty Ltd in Melbourne where he was attached to the Project Australia campaign. That is something I will mention in a minute. That is relevant in view of the comments I want to make on Project Australia and campaigns like it which I would argue are being funded in a way which promotes conservative governments at public expense.

I return to the answer which Senator Chaney gave me. It is not really a suitable explanation-except, for example, for mafia leaders in the United States of America-in answer to an allegation that they have done something wrong or are doing something which is improper in terms of what should happen in a democratic society to say: 'Well, look, other people do that too'. That is heading towards the lowest common denominator of political standards when a Minister gives that sort of answer to a question. Of course, the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Carrick, who is sitting in the chamber tonight, is a master of that sort of answer. The answer to everything that this Government is criticised about is, of course: 'Oh, the other lot did this too'. It is an extraordinary argument to be advanced by a Minister in a government which was elected on the basis that it could do better.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I always say we do it better-always. You have the story wrong.
—I think I could put a heap of copies of Hansard on your desk which would--
—Which would say 'you did it worse'. I acknowledge that.

—No. Senator Carrick understands the point I am making. He is very sensitive about it because it has been his stock answer in Question Time for as long as I can remember. He says: 'We are not bad in relation to these things because the Whitlam Government was bad too. Therefore, that makes us all right'. That is an absolutely childish proposition-my daddy is a policeman type of argument-and one which, as I have said, is appropriate to the mafia in the United States. It is a 'be nice to us and we will be nice to you' sort of argument. It is not an appropriate argument in terms of political standards and high public life in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I was making the point that in a sense the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has taken a leaf out of the Premiers' books-the Premiers to whom I referred-in establishing the Government Information Unit. Of course the whole idea of the Government Information Unit is to prevent the Government being accountable in any real sense. The operatives, if I can use that expression, of the Government Information Unit are placed on the staffs of Ministers in each of the capital cities where they are euphemistically described as liaison officers. During the last election campaign the members of the Unit were engaged in electioneering for the Liberal Party--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—I make that charge and I invite the Government to deny it by argument and not by interjection. Those liaison officers wrote speeches, made tapes and were engaged in contact work with media outlets. They were extensions of the Liberal Party's campaign office directed by Bob Baudino and the man hired to run the media campaign, the Canberra lobbyist, Jonathan Gaul. Their activities were quite blatant. Any number of journalists in the Press Gallery in Canberra can tell honourable senators about their activities at various capital cities around the country during the last election campaign. Those people were paid with taxpayers' money and they were asked to work for the Liberal Party. They did work for the Liberal Party during the election campaign. That is an allegation which I make and happily invite the Government to deny it because if it wants to get into the details of the matter it will be able to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the activities of these people were quite blatant. This misuse of taxpayers' money is now to be extended by the expansion of this Government Information Office. More staff are to be engaged, so encouraged was the Prime Minister at the prospect of getting propaganda work carried out at no expense to the Liberal Party during the last election campaign. One of the new recruits for this Unit is to be a gentleman whose job it will be to sell or flog rehearsed statements by Ministers on cassette tapes. These tapes will go to radio stations around the country at enormous cost. Of course, the aim again will be to by-pass journalists and prevent awkward questioning. In doing that the Government will be selling policies like soap. Of course, many of the details of its policies bear a lot of resemblance to soap. But that is what the Government is doing. It will be marketing its policies like soap and it will be circumventing the democratic process by not allowing Ministers to answer questions and not forcing the fact that Ministers sometimes have to face up to difficult questions. All these statements will be pre-packaged in cassettes and sent around the country to be played on radio stations around Australia.

As I have said, the aim is to by-pass journalists, to by-pass one of the most important elements of a democratic society. The fourth estate of the French Republic will be by-passed in Malcolm Fraser's society-Australia in the 1980s. If that is in store for us by cassettes being distributed to radio stations, no doubt it is also in the minds of some of the advisers of the Government that it can be in store for us in a television operation in which the same methods are used-cassette recordings being traded as pre-packaged programs to television stations around the country. I raise this issue in the Senate because it is only 1981. It is not 1984 in Australia and this society should not be behaving as if in 1981 we had reached Orwell's 1984 by instituting this method of disseminating propaganda.

I notice that Senator Bjelke-Petersen is in the chamber. In all these matters her husband, as Premier of Queensland, has more guts than the Fraser Government in the way he deals with the Press because he is not afraid to answer questions. I do not think he ever answers a question-I must say that-but that may be a political skill which he has. He is not afraid to mix with the Press and be subjected to questions. That is the sort of objection which I have about the Fraser Government: It is afraid to be subjected to questioning. Hence we are to have this sort of pre-packaged programming which will go out on cassettes to radio and television stations.

The Government Information Unit supposedly now costs something under $300,000 a year to run. But the real cost of the upgraded operation will be not less than $500,000 a year. It will cost $500,000 a year to run this creaky propaganda machine. For example, the Government will spend in two years more of the taxpayers' money than the Labor Party Australia-wide spent in the whole of the last Federal election campaign. In two years it will spend that amount of taxpayers' money. As I have said, I am concerned that that is not a good thing for Australian society and not a good thing even for Ministers in the Fraser Government because in time they will get terribly like the product which is packaged-less nimble witted than they have been, and that is saying something.

This, of course, is not the end of the categories of advertising in which the Fraser Government is currently engaged. It is not the end of the sort of propaganda war which the Prime Minister is concerned to engage in from day to day. The Prime Minister has also tapped another important market-the jingo market-in quite a sophisticated way. Not that I am suggesting that the Prime Minister is sophisticated about jingoes; he has the sophistication, perhaps, to employ sophisticated advisers on this matter. Let us look, for example, at the programs I refer to as being in the third category of advertising, one of which is dealt with in the Australian Manufacturing Council report for 1979-80. I refer to Project Australia. I recommend Project Australia for the gentle attention of the razor gang. The expenditure of some $4m of taxpayers' money could be got rid of with one slash, and this country would be no worse off.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be better off.
—It would be much better off; I will come to that. The 'Life. Be in it' campaign has been rumoured to have come to the attention of the razor gang. It is another great bottomless fount--
—Are you opposed to it, too?

—I am. I think it is a phoney campaign. It is another bottomless pit into which government money is being poured. I understand that that has been mentioned as a possible victim of the razor gang. I invite the razor gang to turn its Sweeney Todd attentions to Project Australia as well. In my view that is the most damaging campaign to this society. Project Australia was started with the best intentions in the world. They are all revealed in the Manufacturing Council report.

SPEECH.PARA: The intentions of Project Australia were to encourage people to buy Australian goods. That is very laudable, but the Prime Minister's advisers got hold of the thing and saw it as a way of doing something which this Government has consistently failed to do and which this country really needs. The Government saw it as a canned, pre-packaged method of encouraging community pride, nationalism and so on in this country. The campaign is supposed to generate a positive sense of community purpose as a basis for a reinvigorated Australia. We all share a common concern about a reinvigorated Australia. Millions of voters in this country in 1975 and 1977 voted for a government which promised a reinvigorated Australia. The voters believed, as Malcolm Fraser put it, that he would turn on the lights and create a new and just society in which nobody would be out of work, in which Medibank would be retained, in which we would have good health services and full employment and in which everybody would be stimulated by the private enterprise goal of initiative and so on. That was the sort of society which was to be created; that is why the electors voted for Malcolm Fraser. Five years later, after he has failed in all these aims and does not talk about them any more, a phoney sort of thing called Project Australia is created.

I want to make myself quite clear. Senator Carrick interjected about the 'Life. Be in it' campaign. There is not one tittle of evidence that any Australian is healthier because of the millions of dollars that have been poured into the campaign. Some surveys show that people like the advertisements. They like the character called Norm. Many of them can identify with him, I suppose. They like the advertisements because they are good quality. An important thing to say about Project Australia and 'Life. Be in it.' is that they are examples of good Australian talent at work creating very skilful advertisements. What is the purpose of it all? What is the result of taxpayers' moneys being spent on these programs? Month after month one can see the figures which show higher rates of consumption of alcohol, cigarettes and so on. There is no evidence that society is any healthier at all. There is stacks of evidence that these programs are costing a lot of money and that all the people really like about the campaigns are the advertisements.

I turn more importantly to Project Australia. Project Australia, through its jingles on television and radio, is saying: 'Look! You Australians out there are a lot of slobs. You are all too lazy. If only you got off your backsides and worked harder this would be a great country'. Such a campaign is turning the responsibility which the Fraser Government accepted in terms of its own rhetoric-it said that it would provide leadership in this country and a new sort of society-on to the people. It is also blaming the failure of the Fraser Government on the people of this country. The Government is saying to the people: 'You get to work, and work harder. That is what is wrong with this country'. The Government is saying that the fault lies with the people and not with the leaders, the politicians and the statesmen, so-called. It is saying: 'We are not wrong. We are not failing to provide leadership. You people out there are responsible for the ills of this country'. I invite anybody to read the jingles of Project Australia and to reach any other conclusion. The jingles of Project Australia are directed at putting the blame for a lack of national leadership and the national crisis on the Australian people and taking the blame away from Malcolm Fraser. The result is that this society will become more and more divided if taxpayers' money at a similar rate-$4m has already been spent on Project Australia-continues to be spent on these phoney campaigns.

These phoney campaigns are a waste of taxpayers' money. They are attempts to take responsibility off the Government and to put it on the people. Do honourable senators remember the great sayings of Bertolt Brecht, the German playwright, who said that the government had lost confidence in the people; the government had decided to dismiss the people? That is what is happening with Project Australia. The Government has lost confidence in the people. It is not a question of the people losing confidence in the Government-as yet. These sorts of campaigns not only evade responsibility but also, in my view, are calculated to encourage, in the long term, cynicism about the political process and governments in this country. That is a bad thing.

I would like to deal with one other aspect of Government-funded campaigns. Why did the Government, in financing Project Australia, use the Task Quantum advertising agency, one of the Liberal Party's polling organisations, to develop this campaign? One wonders whether Task Quantum, the advertising agency, did its research into community attitudes in Australia for the Project Australia campaign with an eye to the needs of Tony Eggleton, the national secretary of the Liberal Party, and with an eye to the fortunes of the Liberal Party. Did Tony Eggleton have any input in deciding the brief for Project Australia polling? Did he have any input into the questions people were asked about what they thought of Project Australia and what they thought about the sense of nationalism and unity in this country? Was any special research material given to Eggleton by Task Quantum as a private arrangement? In Perth during the recent election campaign allegations emerged of dirty tricks being carried out by George Camakaris, the principal of Task Quantum, on behalf of the Liberal Party. That was mentioned in all the newspapers. I wonder who else got taxpayers' money out of Project Australia? I suspect, for one, International Public Relations. I have referred already to the activities of Mr Leggoe, now in Western Australia, who is a former director of International Public Relations. On March 21 this year the editorial of the Sydney Morning Herald stated:

Last financial year the Federal Government spent more than $15m on advertising, much of it on television. This year the figure will be considerably higher and there will be more emphasis on television. The not-so-underlying theme of much of it is Australia, the Lucky Country, with some beaut, cheery suggestions on how to make it even even luckier.

By the end of this financial year Project Australia, as I said, will have cost about $4m. Project Australia is being accused of dealing in hopeful generalities rather than trying to change the actual conditions under which people work.

The reality of this country, as of every other country, is simply that pride in a country is created by people knowing that it is a just society in which things are done well, in which technical standards are high and in which technology is innovative; when people can look ahead and say: 'My children are going to grow up in a society without two million living in poverty, in a society where there are not unemployed people and work is shared, in a society where there are opportunities for all and there is, as near as possible, equality of opportunity, and in a society which can stand on its own two feet in the rest of the world and say: Here in Australia we do things in a fair way and in a skilled way; we are a lucky country and we are entitled to be lucky because of the efforts we put into it'. They are the sorts of attitudes which will encourage a healthy and forward looking nationalism in this country and which can make us all proud of the society in which we live. The sort of phoney nationalism shown in the attitudes of Project Australia, which are simply, as I said, to divert the blame from the Government to the people of this country and which use these alleged skills of advertising agencies to encourage a sort of false charge in people like a few glasses of beer do for some, is not something we want. The Government, in my view, is to be roundly condemned for wasting the taxpayers' money on this sort of activity-the third tier of advertising in which the Fraser Government engages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of the first reading of this legislation to refer to what the Northern Territory News calls a conspiracy of silence. Before I do so I would like to compliment my leader on his excellent speech. He raised vital issues to which the Government could well give attention. It is a pity that we were not on air to have allowed other people to hear the speech. It is a pity that there were only twelve honourable senators on this side of the chamber and three on the other side to listen to such an excellent speech. I am afraid that what I have to say will not have the same quality in terms of either rhetoric or content, but it is still important to me and to the people of the Northern Territory.
—Honesty is a very bad fault to fall into in this place.

—I will take note of that. I have plenty of examples of the other. The conspiracy of silence referred to in the Northern Territory News involves plans to use City Council land, Federal Government land, a street in Darwin and the resumption of private land to enable a hotel-convention centre to be built by a foreign company. This foreign company has its base in Sabah. I understand that this hotel-convention centre-performing arts centre will cost about $40m. While referring to this I will also refer to the broader issues, and put this proposition: What protection have people got when local government and State government-in this case the Territory Government-collude against the wishes of the people of that place, if it is against the wishes of the people? I will refer to that later.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give a little background. The former Mayor of Darwin, Dr Stack, arranged for land for a performing arts centre. This was to be her monument-something she would leave behind after her period in office. The land she acquired to do this consisted of the old Town Hall site, a block of land owned by a southern newspaper as the residence for its local correspondent and two blocks owned by the Federal Government. Plans were drawn up for this centre-an excellent proposition-and money was collected. Some money was allocated from the Tracy fund to assist in the building of this place. Unbeknown to the people of Darwin, the Northern Territory Government and the present mayor have been negotiating with a foreign company, the company to which I referred. I read from the 26 March 1981 edition of the Northern Territory News which is a staunch supporter of the Northern Territory Government. In part of the editorial it had this to say:

In one of the most secretive government deals this newspaper has uncovered it appears Darwin's hopes and dreams for a full-scale performing arts complex have been sold out to a foreign company . . . For not until today has the public had any inkling that the Northern Territory Government and Darwin City Corporation have been furtively carrying out a deal with a Malaysian company for a big hotel complex on prime public land previously designated for the arts complex.
The proposal entails-again I read directly from the front page of the 26 March issue of the Northern Territory News:
Hotel, convention centre and theatre complex to be built by a foreign company.
The Darwin City Council to relinquish two blocks earmarked for a community performing arts centre.
The Federal Government to relinquish two adjoining blocks.
McLachlan Street between Mitchell Street and the Esplanade to be closed.
The complex to extend across the closed street and on to three blocks opposite.

These are owned (1) by a pastoral company of which Tourism and Primary Production Minister, Roger Steele, is a director; (2) architects and town planners Stapledon Vos Pty Ltd and (3) former Northern Territory Port Authority chairman, Captain Tom Milner.

I understand Mr Steele, the Minister, is quite happy for his company to sell its land. Captain Milner has not been approached and certainly is not happy to sell, but the matter has not been discussed with him at all. What are the major objections I want to raise tonight to the proposition? The first is the secrecy-there has been no consultation with the Northern Territory people. This once again is a concern to us. It was referred to by my leader in the comments he made about the Government's losing faith in the people. The Government of the Northern Territory does not involve the people in its decision-making, and I think this is a disadvantage. I have drawn attention to this previously. There has been no consultation with the aldermen either. Honourable senators will have noticed that I was careful to refer to the Mayor of Darwin and not the Corporation. I read again from the Northern Territory News, this time from the 27 March edition:
Darwin aldermen are believed to be angry about being left out of preliminary negotiations.
They knew nothing until the proposal was presented to them as a fait accompli last Friday.
They were simply told about it and advised that Mr McHenry--
He is the co-ordinator for the Northern Territory Government-
would be present to talk to them.
They were so in the dark they boycotted the talk until they had a chance to discuss it among themselves.
One alderman told The NT News: 'It appears the Government is railroading the proposal through before anybody can protest.
'It was the same with the Mindil Beach casino deal-we were told the day before the Government announcement.
'We feel we have been sold down the drain.
Everything has gone on behind closed doors with no consultation whatever, even with those who will be using the place.
'The whole thing has been pretty murky and I for one am very cross'.

In that instance he referred to the fact that there has been no consultation with the people who will be using it. One of the groups that would be using it would be the Northern Territory Arts Council. I refer to a comment made by Ms Liz Andrew who was administrator of the Council. Again I read from the Northern Territory News of 27 March:
Administrator of the NT Arts Council, Ms Liz Andrew is concerned at the lack of consultation over the whole affair.
'A couple of individuals have come to us and talked about what we think but there has been no sitting down around the table for serious discussion.
'It got to the stage we were finding out things because somebody dropped bits here and there.
'We certainly have not been shown any plans.'

My second objection to the proposition is the change in the design. To fit the performing arts complex within the hotel the size of the hall, originally designed for 1,200, has been reduced to a 1,000-seating capacity. This is obviously not economical. A professional theatre director, Simon Hopkinson, made the comment that ballet and similar shows need double the size to cover costs. Ms Andrew, to whom I have already referred as the administrator of the Northern Territory Arts Council, said:
The reduction from 1,200 to 1,000 means the loss of $3,000 per night for shows like Evita and obviously a little less for shows where the costs are not as great.

There has been a loss of rehearsal rooms because in the new complex there will be no space for rehearsal rooms. They have been one of the first casualties. This is very bad, because obviously there will be no appropriate training area. The major hall will be tied up for rehearsals which means that the shows produced will not be produced so well. More importantly, young people and those who are interested in the arts will not have an opportunity for rehearsal and, therefore, will not be able to put on shows. Another thing which concerns us particularly is the loss of what in the original plans was called the performing place-a 250-seat auditorium suitable for dance and intimate drama.

The last point I want to make, although there are other objections, is the association of the complex with the hotel, particularly as it is being built by a foreign group. Certainly there may be advantages-people have claimed advantages-but I would say that the number of disadvantages outweighs them. Ms Andrew of the Northern Territory Arts Council stated:
The other thing that concerns me is that theatre patrons would have to go to the hotel for a drink during interval.
Imagine how tricky this would be during a 15 minute interval.
Frankly I am appalled that Darwin is to get a big, brassy commercial hotel that will only benefit Borneo millionaires.
That land was earmarked years ago for a performing arts centre for the people, now we're getting a hotel.
The Government built a museum and art gallery and a craft centre, and is now discriminating against another section of the arts.

It is disturbing because the Government could have maintained the original concept. It dithered and it lost the opportunity. Building costs now have escalated to between $15m and $17m, and that is beyond the resources which are available to the Council and to the Government. Lest I be accused of knocking development, let me hasten to say that I am not doing that at all. I think the hotel is a good idea. Another hotel for Darwin to boost tourism is an excellent idea. A hotel which provides a good quality convention centre is an excellent idea also. But one must query whether it ought to be in that place and whether it ought to replace the performing arts centre. Obviously, if we are missing this we will lose our free standing cultural centre with all the features that I have mentioned-the rehearsal rooms, the intimate theatre, a fine building which would be an aesthetic addition to the city. We will lose all those things, and the land which was earmarked for a performing arts centre will be used for a hotel.

But my main objection-let me put it again quite clearly-is to the lack of consultation with the people of the Northern Territory. Obviously, we accept the proposition that business needs some privacy, but when public land is involved-both State and Federal land-and when public money and public ambitions are involved, surely the people themselves ought to be involved. There is a difference between getting a good deal in the paternalistic sense for people and riding rough shod over them. My feelings are summed up in the editorial comment which states:

The furtiveness of negotiations between the Northern Territory Government, council and Bena Holdings is staggering considering the involvement of public money, public land and the destruction of the original performing arts centre concept which was long heralded as bringing Darwin to cultural maturity.
Whatever the motives, there has been a conspiracy of silence as far as the public is concerned.
While a major new hotel would certainly be in Darwin's best interests, the trade-off for private development, the lack of public accountability and the buddy-type negotiations require explanation.
As an exercise in how not to go about winning the confidence of people this must rank as a public debacle without peer.

I hasten to add that the Federal Government is involved. It obviously was a party to the deal because Federal land was involved. It must have been a party to the negotiations; it must share some of the criticism.

The action which was taken by the Everingham Government is paternalistic in the worst sense. It is the sort of thing which I have criticised before. The question which must be asked is: What sort of protection can a Federal government offer to citizens of the Territory in an issue such as this? It is not sufficient to say: 'Toss them out at the next elections'. That is not the answer. State and Territory governments obviously must have some autonomy. We accept this and we have worked for it. We have worked to get our own legislative assembly. What concerns me is that I see a situation in which the Federal Government is involved in negotiations and then does not require any assurance that the project which was to go ahead enjoys the support of the Northern Territory people. It must be of concern to us sitting in this chamber to see that the Federal Government is giving to a foreign company land on which to build a hotel. I have said in this place before that an electoral mandate goes only so far, and this has gone beyond it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the text of the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Bill 1981

The Commonwealth Government has, over the years, pursued policies that are aimed at protecting the Australian coastline. In keeping with that history, I am now introducing a package of legislation entitled Protection of the Sea. The package represents a major advance in marine pollution prevention and combat in Australia. These matters have been the subject of detailed discussion with the States in the Marine and Ports Council and also with industry. Australia has been participating for more than thirty years in international organisations that develop international conventions on maritime matters. Australia has a good record in implementing these international agreements after they come into force. Australia as an island continent has a long coastline that, in places, is environmentally extremely sensitive and I believe it is now opportune to introduce legislation to augment the existing law.
The 'Protection of the Sea' legislation package contains the following Bills:

Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Bill, Protection of the Sea (Powers of Intervention) Bill, Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Bill, Navigation (Protection of the Sea) Amendment Bill, Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Bill and Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy Collection) Bill.

The Understandings on Offshore Matters reached at the Premiers Conference in June 1979 provide for Commonwealth legislation on certain matters relating to ship-sourced marine pollution. The six Bills accord with the Understandings. The Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Bill will implement the provisions of the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage 1969 and the 1976 Protocol to that Convention. The Convention requires ships carrying more than 2000 tons of oil in bulk as cargo to maintain insurance to cover liability for pollution damage. The Convention and the Bill provide for ship owners to limit their liability to an amount determined by the size of the ship. The maximum level of compensation available under the provisions of the Convention is in excess of $A14.9m but this amount relates to tankers with a register tonnage of more than 105,000 tons. No tankers of that size trade to Australia. The maximum liability for an incident involving the largest tanker in the Australian fleet would approximate $A7.8m. The Bill preserves the operation of State and Territory laws that give effect to Convention requirements.

I think it is appropriate to outline the other measures that are envisaged by the Protection of the Sea legislation package so that honourable senators will be aware of the interrelationship of the various Bills. The Protection of the Sea (Powers of Intervention) Bill will implement the provisions of the 1969 International Convention Relating to Intervention on the High Seas in Cases of Oil Pollution Casualties. The Bill will also implement the provisions of the 1973 Protocol to that Convention. Where pollution or a threat of a pollution incident exists the Bill empowers the Minister to take any appropriate action on the high seas or in territorial waters in regard to Australian or foreign ships. The Minister will be required to have regard to Convention constraints which are incorporated in the Bill in using this power. The Bill preserves the operation of State and Territory legislation.

Since 1970, Part VIIA of the Navigation Act 1912 has included provisions based on the Civil Liability and Intervention Conventions. The Navigation (Protection of the Seas) Amendment Bill will repeal Part VIIA of the Navigation Act so that the Bills I have just outlined can give full effect to the provisions of the respective Conventions. Part VIIA of the Navigation Act currently contains intervention powers which are broader than the powers conferred by the Convention or Protocol. Australia has always asserted that customary international law provides a nation with powers to protect its territory and coastal sea. The Protection of the Sea (Powers of Intervention) Bill will continue to apply these provisions in Australian pollution legislation.

The Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Bill will repeal and replace the Pollution of the Sea by Oil Act 1960. That Act gives effect to the provisions of the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution of the Sea by Oil. The new Bill picks up the provisions of the 1960 Act and, in addition, will implement the requirements of the two 1971 Amendments to the Convention. The first amendment will provide increased protection to the Great Barrier Reef by prohibiting the operational discharge of oil within or near the Reef by redefining the Convention term 'nearest land'. The new arrangement will ensure that oil is not discharged within 50 miles of the outer edge of the Great Barrier Reef. The second 1971 amendment to the 1954 Convention imposed limits on the size and location of cargo tanks in tankers. The new Bill applies these provisions to Australian ships.

The Navigation (Protection of the Sea) Amendment Bill repeals Part VIIA of the Navigation Act 1912, as I mentioned earlier. It also inserts a new Division 12 in Part IV of the Navigation Act. The new Division imposes requirements on tanker owners and masters in relation to survey, certification and production of certificates. These provisions are included in the Navigation Act to maintain the various survey and construction requirements in one piece of legislation. In addition the Minister will have power to direct foreign tankers to take certain action while the tanker is within the Australian jurisdiction. These powers will be exercised only insofar as it is necessary to do so to protect the environment.

The remaining Bills in the package are the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Bill and the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy Collection) Bill. These Bills respectively repeal and replace the Pollution of the Sea by Oil (Shipping Levy) Act 1972 and the Pollution of the Sea by Oil (Shipping Levy Collection) Act 1972. The new Bills maintain all the provisions of the existing Acts, but change the titles of the legislation to maintain uniformity with the remainder of the legislation package.

The Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Bill includes a new provision to ensure that the minimum amount of levy able to be collected will be maintained at an economic level. In addition, the definition of oil in the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy Collection) Bill has been extended to include a wider range of hydrocarbon pollutants. That establishes the relationship of this Bill to the other Bills in the package. I now commend the Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Bill to honourable senators.
Protection of the Sea (Powers of Intervention) Bill 1981

As I indicated in my second reading speech for the Civil Liability Bill, the Powers of Intervention Bill will implement the 1969 International Convention Relating to Intervention on the High Seas in Cases of Oil Pollution Casualties, and its 1973 Protocol. The Bill contains powers that the Minister may invoke to intervene in an actual or threatened pollution incident. I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Bill 1981

The Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Bill brings the existing provisions in the Pollution of the Sea by Oil Act 1960 into line with other measures in the Protection of the Sea Legislation Package. These provisions implement the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution of the Sea by Oil. The Discharge of Oil from Ships Bill makes provision to bring into force the 1971 Amendments to the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution of the Sea by Oil. These Amendments relate to cargo tank sizes and location in tankers and also make provision for the protection of the Great Barrier Reef. The Pollution of the Sea by Oil Acts 1960, 1965 and 1972 are repealed and replaced by this Bill. I commend this Bill to honourable senators.
Navigation (Protection of the Sea) Amendment Bill 1981

The Navigation (Protection of the Sea) Amendment Bill repeals Part VIIA of the Navigation Act 1912, which contained provisions based on the International Conventions relating respectively to civil liability and intervention on the high seas. In addition, the Bill inserts a new Division 12 in Part IV of the Navigation Act 1912. The new part incorporates certification, survey and certificate production requirements in relation to tankers. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Bill 1981

The Bill repeals and replaces the Pollution of the Sea by Oil (Shipping Levy) Act 1972. The title has been changed to reflect the unity of the 'Protection of the Sea' legislation package. A provision has been included in the Bill which will allow the minimum levy payable by ships to be set by regulation. This minimum levy is not to exceed $25. The purpose of this provision is to ensure that the legislation will not require the collection of amounts of levy that are uneconomic to collect. I commend this Bill to honourable senators.
Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy Collection) Bill 1981

As with the Shipping Levy Bill, this Bill has a changed title from its 1972 predecessor to conform with the 'Protection of the Sea' legislation package. The Bill also includes an amendment to the definition of 'oil' in the 1972 Shipping Levy Collection Act. The new definition of 'oil' extends to both persistent and non-persistent oils. I commend this Bill to honourable senators.

Here we are in this place dealing with legislation on the--

—I do not mean to interfere but we have just had a continuous first reading debate in which every honourable senator could air every matter other than the subject of the Bills. —Senator Carrick, I take it you are raising a point of order. Senator Gietzelt has not spoken for very long and perhaps we could wait a little longer before you speak of relevance.

—The criticisms to which I refer flow from the frustration of the Opposition and the complete irrelevance that the Parliament has in the process of government in this country. We are dealing with legislation which deals with the protection of our seas and with pollution. Even this legislation had its origins in processes which were begun in 1975 and continued in 1978. It is 1981 before we actually have the legislation before the Parliament.
