SPEECH.PARA: The first three of the six Bills we are dealing with seek to implement the provisions of the long-established international conventions and protocols and therefore seek to deal with the civil liabilities arising from pollution, the powers of intervention and the problems occasioned by the discharge of oil from ships. The Navigation (Protection of the Sea) Amendment Bill contains provisions relating to those parts of the three Bills to which I have referred. The other two Bills that we are debating relate to the collection of a levy imposed on the shipping industry to maintain supplies of equipment to combat pollution of the sea by oil. These two Bills, the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy) Bill and the Protection of the Sea (Shipping Levy Collection) Bill, which also are important, are related to the other Bills to which I have referred. These two Bills also seek to repeal and replace existing Acts.

Because Bills similar to these have been considered by the parliaments of many other countries and by international agencies obviously the Opposition will not oppose them. Rather, we will support them. After all, the objective of the legislation is to prevent the pollution of our maritime areas. As Australia is a maritime power, an island continent, it is important that we take steps to protect from pollution our foreshores and other important environmental areas.

The Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Bill seeks to implement the provisions of the 1969 International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage and the 1976 Protocol to that Convention. The Convention has been operative in many other parts of the world since 1975. It operates as an international treaty. The Protocol referred to in this legislation will come into force on 8 April 1981. This Convention and the Protocol were drawn up under the auspices of the Inter-governmental Maritime Consultative Organisation, which is a specialised agency of the United Nations, and acts as the international secretariat or governmental forum, if you like, which debates and drafts all kinds of conventions on maritime matters. In the modern world of today this indicates how important it is for agreements to be reached between governments at the international level on a whole range of matters, particularly those that relate to issues which have some interdependence on and co-operation between countries. It highlights a view that has been expressed so often in the past by those who believe that we need to see the development of a much wider form of a world parliament to handle so many of these issues. With the growth in the internationalisation of industry and of capital and the development of the multinational type corporations in the international sphere which owe allegiance to no particular country and which act in their own interests and often against the interests of individual countries, it is becoming more and more important that we establish some form of international control, some form of international co-operation, some form of international decision making which will establish general forms of behaviour which will mitigate against the sorts of problems of pollution dealt with in this legislation.

The problem of pollution caused by ships is a matter which has concerned many countries for decades. It has taken a good deal of time and energy and understanding on the part of many countries and the companies involved in the transportation of oil by sea to sort out and to establish a code of behaviour which would prevent pollution of the type we have seen in so many parts of the world as oil in particular is moved from one part of the world to another. The IMCO conventions do not themselves constitute maritime law. That maritime law operates in the member states of IMCO. Over 100 countries base their laws upon the agreements to which I have referred. This results in consistent standards being adopted and from time to time amended for the international shipping industry to the advantage of all concerned.

The Protection of the Sea (Civil Liability) Bill requires ships carrying more than 2,000 tonnes of oil in bulk as cargo to maintain insurance certificates to cover their liability for pollution damage that they may cause. We have read from time to time of the tremendous damage that has been done in various parts of the world by ships which for a variety of reasons have created pollution of great magnitude. The Bill enables ship owners to limit their liability to a rate of approximately $142 per tonne of the ship's registered tonnage up to a limit of about $14.9m. The Bill preserves the legislation of a State or Territory and consequently its provisions do not cover intrastate trading vessels. Government non-commercial vessels, basically warships, and Australian fishing vessels on non-overseas voyages are also exempt. The Bill contains adequate penalties against vessels contravening or not complying with its provisions. Ships can be detained by the Minister until the penalty is paid, and that includes foreign ships still within Australian territorial waters. The legislation does not provide for a time limit in relation to prosecutions. When we consider the number of ships that travel our shores and when we consider the problems that could arise for example in the northern part of our continent, particularly around the Great Barrier Reef area, we can appreciate the grave oil pollution difficulties that could arise should a ship's captain not have regard to his obligations under this legislation or to the agreements that have been reached at the international level. The passage of this legislation will establish a standard by which ships, ships' captains and shipowners will accept a greater liability than they have had to accept in the past.

As far as I have been able to establish, Australia is not a contracting state to the IMCO Fund Convention, the International Convention on the Establishment of an International Fund for Compensation for Oil Pollution Damage; neither has it ratified the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships which was signed way back in 1973, eight years ago. The Australian Government does not have a good track record in ratifying these conventions and protocols; nor does it have a good record in relation to implementing the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation in its report into the prevention and control of oil pollution in the marine environment, which report was tabled in 1978. That Committee recommended that the Australian Government ratify the International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers of 1978, which I believe is still unimplemented.

The Protection of the Sea (Powers of Intervention) Bill 1981 seeks to implement the provisions of the 1969 International Convention Relating to Intervention on the High Seas in Cases of Oil Pollution Casualties and the provisions of the 1973 Protocol to that Convention. The Convention was ratified by most countries as far back as 1975. Honourable senators can understand why I have made some criticism of the failure of the Fraser Government to take the sorts of steps that should have been taken years ago to bring these matters before the Parliament. This Bill will permit the Minister to take any measures on the high seas deemed necessary to prevent, mitigate or eliminate dangers to the coastline or related interests of Australia from pollution or the threat of pollution by oil and noxious substances. This covers not only Australian ships but also foreign ships. In cases outside the scope of the convention or protocol reliance is placed on customary international law. Again, the penalties for a breach of the provision or the directions are considered adequate.

The second Bill, the Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Bill 1981, will give effect to the provisions of the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution of the Sea by Oil or its subsequent amendments. This Bill will repeal and replace the Pollution of the Sea by Oil Act 1960 which gave effect to the provisions of the 1954 convention. The two 1971 amendments are of great significance. One of these provides increased protection for the Great Barrier Reef by prohibiting oil discharges within 50 miles of the outer edge of the reef. When this matter was discussed in the Opposition party room some concern was expressed about the fact that we could well have adopted a much stricter limit than 50 miles, bearing in mind that we could have a major pollution problem occurring in that area and that 50 miles probably was not a sufficient distance to ensure safety from ships polluting the reef by discharging substances.

When we had regard to our existing policies of sovereignty in respect of the 200-mile limit the view was expressed that it ought to include 200 miles to the east of the Great Barrier Reef. That, of course, is not provided for in the legislation but I think that it is a matter that the Parliament at some future stage ought to re-examine from the point of view of protecting that wonderful part of our natural heritage, the Great Barrief Reef. Under our federal jurisdiction the Bill, of course, strictly prohibits the deliberate discharge of oil or oily substances into the seas. The Bill preserves the operation of State and Territorial legislation which covers territorial seas and island waters. Overall, the Bill is an important piece of legislation. It establishes processes by which the States, in co-operation with the Commonwealth, will exercise new powers over the control of pollution.

I think that there is enough empirical evidence to show that there is an important need for the legislation to be operative as quickly as possible and to establish the processes and procedures by which we can keep under surveillance ships operating in our waters. For example, the Department of Transport, during tanker inspections between 1 August 1977 and 31 December 1978, discovered that out of 230 ships inspected 122 demonstrated deficiencies. That accounts for over half of the ships inspected. Moreover, there were 480 deficiencies from the 122 inspections. A great many of the problems or deficiencies arising from the inspections were found in flags of convenience vessels. I think we know enough about the way in which vessels flying a flag of convenience operate to know that they are largely irresponsible and largely do not properly apply themselves to areas of responsibility as far as member states and governments are concerned. They take an independent position. The purpose of this legislation, of course, is to bring them much more under the influence and control of countries in which they operate.

Another reason for the legislation's importance is demonstrated by the figures showing that between 1 June 1976 to May 1977 there were almost 90 reported oil pollution incidents from ships around Australia. For example, from 1 January 1978 to 31 December 1980 there were 85 oil spills in Botany Bay. This is an area with which I have very close relations because it is near where I live. According to the Maritime Services Board of New South Wales 309,400 litres of oil were spilt in Botany Bay in the decade 1970-80. Whilst it is conceded that many of these spills were small the continual slow release of oil from repeated spills in a confined space such as a harbour or bay, as happened in Botany Bay, is detrimental to marine development. Of course, it is well known that Botany Bay is one of the most important oyster producing areas of our country. It is not only a favourite recreational area but it also has particular significance for the oyster farming industry. Of course, many varieties of birds and fish, as well as mangrove swamps, exist in that area. Despite this we have had continual problems of pollution in this area from oil carrying vessels.

For example, with the holing of the ship World Encouragement in September 1979 in Botany Bay 20 tonnes of crude oil escaped. The costs of oil pollution in environmental damage, clean-up costs and civil damage suits were high indeed in that area. These areas need to be protected and the persons responsible for these mishaps have to be put in a position where they pay the penalty. This legislation will go some way towards combating pollution of the sea by oil as a result of the establishment of Australian joint Federal-State machinery to combat oil pollution from ships in our waters.

I find it strange that in the second reading speech not once did the Minister mention the national plan which, after all, is a very important part in protecting the environment of our Australian waters. This is a co-operative process by which Commonwealth and State administrations will play a considerable and important new part in protecting our natural environment from the sort of pollution so prominent in our Australian waters in the last 20 or 30 years. The legislation will take some steps toward establishing important new processes by which those responsible for the mistakes of the past will now be subject to a process under which they will pay the penalties deserved for their inconsiderate treatment of our environment. If there is a deficiency in the legislation certainly it will be shown up. To the extent that the Opposition has considered the legislation, it believes there are some deficiencies, nevertheless the legislation will be given its support. We in the Opposition express the hope that the absolutely vital co-operation between the Commonwealth and State instrumentalities will result in important improvements in protecting our marine environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing the package of what is known as the protection of the sea legislation. Certainly, at this stage of the evening I am not going to enumerate all the Bills involved. As everybody knows, Australia is an island continent. As a result, it has a very long coastline. It is generally recognised that we can attribute our vast tourist inflow to part of that coastline. Indeed, we have some of the best beaches in the world, as anybody who travels will recognise. Oil spills can cause devastation to those beaches and some of the coastal wonders.

SPEECH.PARA: In a speech on 28 February 1979 I went into more detail than I will go into tonight on the effects of drilling on the Great Barrier Reef and what would happen if something went wrong and there was an oil spill or a blowout. I pointed out that as bad as it was, it was not necessarily as devastating as one would first think. It is quite noticeable that since then I have been joined by some very good company. As recently as about a week ago I noticed that famed television naturalist, Harry Butler, agreed with my general assumption. The point that I made in that speech was that generally a vastly different amount of oil comes from a spill than from a wrecked ship. I said:

The supertanker Amoco Cadiz, which went down off the cost of Brittany, released 220,000 tonnes of oil. The Torrey Canyon, which went down of the coast of England, released 100,000 tonnes of oil. The blowout on the Ekofisk Bravo Oil platform in the North Sea which continued for some days released only 22,500 tons of oil. The Santa Barbara blowout released only 10,000 to 20,000 tons of oil.

To that point in time that was a good argument, but I must confess, being rather objective, that the Ixtoc oil well leakage in the Gulf of Mexico even though it was a one-off situation has shot those statistics a little to blazes because that well unfortunately was unable to be capped. It went for about nine months and I believe in total it released approximately 410,000 tonnes of oil. We could probably look at that as a one-off situation and still come back to the fact that I concluded with in that speech. I stated:

Even if we do not drill the reef for another thousand years the very thing that we fear could happen tomorrow, the next day or the day after because of all the shipping movements up and down the coast. We have a far greater problem on our plate because of ship movements around the world than we are ever likely to have from any oil drilling.
On 9 October 1980 the New Scientist which looked at the results of the Ixtoc well a few months later stated:
The Ixtoc oil well in the Gulf of Mexico began leaking in the summer of 1979
That is, the northern summer--
and wasn't capped successfully until the spring of this year. During that time, about 150 million gallons of crude oil-
Or 410,000 tonnes-

spilled into the Gulf, leaving many of the beaches along the south coast of Texas awash with goo. Scientists now say that, despite the massiveness of the spill, little permanent environmental damage was done.

Both the commercial fishing industry and the many recreational sites are coming back to normal already, according to Edward B. Overton of the Centre for Bio-Organic Studies at the University of New Orleans. The main cleansing agent has been the environment itself, particularly the co-operative weather patterns that helped to disperse the oil and render it more vulnerable to natural degradative forces. According to most preliminary findings, the Gulf is proving itself remarkably resilient, as Overton and the other participants at an assessment symposium agreed.

We dislike intensely any possibility of any oil spills along our coast. We know the immediate aesthetic problems that result from oil spills on the beaches and the devastation caused among bird life, but all is not as bad as it could first be construed. The environment does have a natural cleansing effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you happy with the Federal Government co-operating with the States on such oil disasters?
—I am not sure to what the honourable senator is referring.
—With the Oceanic Grandeur disaster the Queensland Government was not happy with the collaboration it got from Canberra.

—I think the honourable senator is probably right. However, there has been fair co-operation regarding this Bill. The Federal Minister is given certain powers which I will mention at the end of my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Gietzelt mentioned in relation to the Barrier Reef, the amendments cover two important aspects. The first gives improved protection for the Great Barrier Reef by prohibiting operational discharge of oil within or near the outer reef by measuring nearest land from the outer edge of the Reef. In other words, there can now be no operational discharge by any tanker or ship cleaning bilges within the area of the reef. I believe this must take place outside 50 miles of the outer edge of the reef which will give us more protection than we currently have. Probably people who are unscrupulous enough to do it will do it in the hope that they can get away with it.

It is interesting to note that the major maritime nations, other than the United States of America, are amongst the 40 parties to this Convention. I understand that the United States prefers a global scheme that deals with oil spills from any source, for example, off-shore oil spills. That concerns me a little. I understand that insurance is carried, but I hope that the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) will give me more detail on the United States as it sees its responsibility regarding oil spills on the coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is anti-American.

—It may not be anti-American, it may be that America wants to see a better regime in force, but in the meantime I hope that we have adequate protection. This legislation also gives the Minister power-I take up the point that Senator Mulvihill discussed with me-to take action where pollution or a threat of pollution exists. The Bill empowers the Minister to take any appropriate action on the high seas or in territorial waters in regard to Australian or foreign ships. I think the incident which stands out most in our minds is the Amoco Cadiz which I have mentioned-when it lost steerageway off the coast of Brittany. As I understand it a haggle was going on between salvage tugs and the marshal of the vessel. They could not reach agreement and in the meantime the ship went aground. This resulted in a massive oil spill which, I think everybody agreed, was basically unnecessary. If a similar incident happened off an Australian port-I believe a similar situation happened off Newcastle-the Minister is empowered to do something about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to think regulations are now such that there is a back-up or an emergency system whereby a ship can be steered. Another thing that concerns me is that it appears that with very large, modern tankers in certain conditions, such as tidal rips in the English Channel, the anchors are not capable of holding the ships. That situation probably goes beyond the provisions in this legislation, but if the Minister has any information on that matter I would be pleased to hear it. I certainly want to hear about the situation regarding the United States and whether shipping that plies within Australian waters is now bound to have any emergency steering system available. I support the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I state my views on this legislation I will clarify a couple of matters that emerged in the dialogue that ensued between Senator Collard and me. Firstly one has to go back in history to the advent of the Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution under the chairmanship of Senator Gordon Davidson. That was the first Senate committee that delved into oil pollution. We had another illustrious South Australian, Senator Clem Ridley--
—Were you on that Committee?
—Yes, I was. That Committee was a trail-blazer.
—The Senate Select Committee on Off-shore Petroleum Resources ran it pretty closely.

—We all have our place in the sun. I want to clarify the reference I made to the United States. I did not want it to be construed that I was critical of the United States. On the contrary, when the Davidson committee was in full flight, we were indebted to the Senator from Maine, Senator Ed Muskie, who later held a very high office in the Carter Administration. He is a man well known to Senator Wheeldon. He always emphasised in correspondence I received from him, maximum damages. They are referred to in this legislation. He visualised a situation, which I will come to later, about the indemnification for jumbo tankers not being as full as we imply it is in this legislation. At the time of the Oceanic Grandeur disaster a very efficient Minister for Transport, the Honourable Charles Jones, made amendments to the Navigation Act. Of course there was provision for a government to claim damages but there was little to assist owners of small craft.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say in fairness to Senator Carrick that those of us who attended a briefing on the matter were given to understand that the Navigation Act and TOVALOP, the Tanker Owners Voluntary Agreement concerning liability for oil pollution-a private oil company indemnification scheme-have been consolidated to give a far more effective cover.

Like my colleague, Senator Gietzelt, I still remain unconvinced that sufficient provision has been made to cover oil slicks left by unknown vessels. It may be argued that Australian taxpayers are not ready to pay for an effective coast guard service such as the United States and Canada have. It may be argued that better aerial surveillance is the answer but I notice from the statistics that Senator Gietzelt referred to-they have been available to me for a couple of years-that there is a grey area, or a puzzling area. On occasions we suspect who is responsible for certain oil slicks but we cannot sheet home a prosecution.

As Senator Gietzelt also mentioned, even small spillages have a cumulative effect on marine life. This is a great problem we are confronted with at the moment. I know that recently there appeared in the National Times a series of articles which indicated what was going on all round the world. Probably every couple of months in New South Wales what is called a minor spillage occurs in Botany Bay. Of course, the effect such a spillage has on marine life is enormous.

These are things that I hope the Minister will take on board. Coming from the premier State he will recall the master of a Liberian tanker who had a verbal fracas with the Maritime Services Board. I am not questioning whether the ship's master had all the necessary qualifications to pilot his own vessel, but after the incident he disappeared out of the port of Sydney. I hope that a permanent black ban has been placed on him so that if he should arrive at Fremantle or come in to a northern port we would insist that he take his ship away.

I wish to put what may be a hypothetical case to the Minister's advisers. Senator Collard, quite rightly, was concerned about pollution of the Great Barrier Reef. The Bills refer to documentation. As I read the legislation, the master of a vessel entering the port of Fremantle would have to produce documents at Gauge Roads so that we could see whether they met our standards. I often wonder what would happen if a jumbo tanker-I use that term in a broad sense-on a maiden voyage had a mishap in the Torres Strait. In my dialogue with Senator Collard I referred to the Oceanic Grandeur. I do not know whether one would call it nature or divine providence, but the currents took all the oil slick from that tanker to Papua New Guinea, not to Australia, as the Minister would know.

I have several questions that I did not get answers for in my briefing. I think there was a broad out of court settlement in relation to the Oceanic Grandeur but had the case gone to court it would have been determined in Hong Kong. I am certainly not so ultra-nationalistic as to suggest that such cases should not be heard in foreign courts but I would like to know what would happen in the event of any subsequent oil disasters in the Torres Strait or off the coast at Fremantle. Even if a spillage occurs outside our 200-mile limit, I wonder whether the offending oil company, with its multinational legal eagles behind it, would be prepared to defend itself in an Australian court or whether it would want to take the case to a court in Colombo, Hong Kong, in which case we would have to put up counsel and fight the case on neutral ground. I think it is very important that, despite all the verbiage in this Bill, we are sure of these things.

I interjected during Senator Collard's speech because of what happened following the Torrey Canyon disaster in the English Channel. The United Kingdom Government and the French Government used different methods of coping with the situation. We can get into difficulties of terminology when we talk of dispersants and detergents. I know there are now even more modern treatments. It depends on which popular science journal one reads whether one can believe that the marine life on the French and British sides of the English Channel has been rehabilitated. I know that my colleague, Senator Georges, has always been a very strong guardian of the Great Barrier Reef. It is inevitable that there will be human failures. It is no use running away with the idea that that is not the case. I know that Senator Collard in response to an interjection claimed that the Queensland marine authority was very critical of the Federal Department of Transport and its officers. There was some difference of opinion. In fairness to Senator Carrick's advisers, I acknowledge that during a briefing we were told that a united front is to be adopted to ensure that we use the best possible dispersants or detergents. I say that with some feeling, because during the Davidson committee proceedings it was made apparent that some States, to be blunt, were conned by various overseas oil companies as to which company could offer the best treatment. When my party's environment committee was briefed by the Minister's officers we were told that we had a very tight ship now. That statement was reinforced by what Senator Collard said, namely, that every State of the Commonwealth takes a hard line before it adopts a new technique. I would like some confirmation of that.
Mr Gladwyn Hill, national environment correspondent for the New York Times, summed up the crux of my reservations when he wrote:

A major reason tankers have been coming to grief at a world wide rate of one or two a month is cheap-john practices of some oil and transport companies. Adequate antispill features are skimmed in vessel construction; tankers are handed down like used cars to less and less scrupulous operators until they are ready to fall apart, and manning and navigation are sometimes shockingly bad. On top of this, many vessels have made a practice of flushing their tanks at sea, releasing tons of waste oil at a time.

There is a very fine work of fiction entitled Rotterdam Delivery, which is about hijackers taking over a tanker. The fact is that the less time a ship is in port the more exhausted a crew becomes. Smaller crews, of, say, four top master mariners and others who do not quite have the necessary skills, are more accident prone. When I say that I am fortified by the Merchant Service Guild of Australia. I have tabled correspondence from the Guild at Estimates committees. I know that when the Estimates for the Department of Transport were under consideration the Department argued that it was aware of these things but that it had the situation well in hand.

This brings me back to my original interjection about United States reservations during Senator Collard's speech. I certainly do not underwrite every United States Government utterance but I know that if this country were to insist that any oil tanker that was over five years old, such as those old Liberian and Panamanian flag ships referred to in the article from which I have quoted, should be banned from Australian coastal waters, there would be less chance of a maritime mishap. What happens at times-I have had correspondence with Ministers about this-is that we take the attitude that there is a very tight market for fuel and that if we get tough with some of these oil companies we will not get any oil at all. It is a debatable point. An oil company failing to observe efficient seamanship and old tankers may say: 'The ships are not allowed to operate in the United States on either coast; send them out to the antipodes'. It would not be the first time that Australia has been sold short.

I would like to feel that we will get very tough with every oil company. Anyone can study the record of the international trade union movement in relation to Panamanian ships and Liberian ships. Under the International Labour Organisation convention, the masters of those ships are the mavericks. The crews are overworked and inefficient and incompetent people are employed. Some of the people on the bridge are working excessive hours, which can cause all sorts of problems. I say that because some honourable senators would well remember that last year a scenario was published in the Australian of what could go wrong and cause a navigation mishap in Bass Strait. I believe that as a result of that script procedures were tightened up. We know that owing to human frailties mishaps can occur. I argue that if we purge ourselves of the old tankers-say, the ones built more than five years ago-we would have lesss chance of these mishaps occurring.

I turn to the matter of penalty provisions. I do not know how far they should be enforced. I know the words 'ministerial discretion' always appear. I will not enumerate the various oil companies and all their charters. People can go to a Minister and ask for clemency. We know what can happen in that situation. I suppose that sort of situation is not covered in this legislation. I know of several aras on our coast which could be involved. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) went to Japan over three years ago to negotiate the migratory bird treaty. I do not think it had to be ratified by all the States. I have not asked lately how many States have not fulfilled their commitments. I say to anyone who gives lip-service to wildlife and bird conservation that we know what has happened in the North Sea and the English Channel. Senator Collard mentioned all the carnage of bird life that occurred off the coast of the United States of America and in the Gulf of Mexico.

I mention one other point, namely, costs which the polluter must pay. I do not see that there should be any fears about levies and how far we really screw these people. I do not say that in an impolite way. I think people know what I am getting at. We do not want to have any inhibitions about the imposition of levies. The legislation deals with the matter of tanker mishaps. While we have off-shore drilling in Bass Strait, we will probably have other development projects carried out by Esso-BP off the Australian coast. Senator Carrick, who is the Minister in charge of these Bills would be delighted if that were to occur, and I suppose in some ways Australia would be delighted.

I have with me a document from the Louisiana Wildlife and Fisheries Commission. I remind the Minister that the Commission puts on the oil company which has a lease a levy in relation to wildlife and conservation. I will not go into the details about what will happen in relation to this legislation because the President might call me to order. We have our own views about what a State government should do in relation to an area within a certain distance of the shore and what the Federal Government should do. I would like to believe that if we were to conduct off-shore drilling of the sort carried out in Bass Strait we would emulate the Louisiana wildlife people and impose a special levy for wildlife conservation. The Commission has established a fund. With the money it receives from companies operating in off-shore areas it is able to buy other land. The system probably operates something like the system covering our own conservation grants.

I think we all welcome this legislation. I received a letter in October 1979 when the then Minister for Transport, Mr Nixon, promised this legislation. I know we were caught up with all the nations in discussions on conventions of the sea and that sort of thing. I conclude by saying that I hope the Minister in reply will clarify some of the fears I have about jumbo tankers. Also I ask: If a mishap occurs in Torres Strait involving a foreign registered vessel or a chartered vessel, can we test the case and claim our damages in Australian courts or do we have to take our chances in a court in Hong Kong where justice might not be the same?

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Senate is debating a package of Bills which could be described briefly as protection of the sea legislation. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gietzelt rightly mentioned that there was a House of Representatives oil spills report. Indeed, it was a very good report. Many of its recommendations have been implemented. The matter was raised, I think by Senator Collard, of the American attitude to civil liability. I am advised that the United States of America does not consider the limits of civil liability sufficiently high and, therefore, it has imposed a levy on all oil. This is aimed at providing a fund of $200m to deal with oil from any source. The United States takes that view. The Australian attitude is that we should not take unilateral action but seek to work within the international forum.

A number of matters have been raised. I will refer to liaison with the States. There is, of course, close liaison with the States. This liaison has been developed through a national plan. The latest development is a working group involving the Commonwealth. The States and the Northern Territory. This group will provide proposals for the purchase of oil combat equipment for training and funding. Equipment and training will be available throughout Australia for use by the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory. Indeed, one of the first functions of the Australian Maritime College in Launceston was to consider tanker handling to avoid spillages and to obviate risks in that area.

Senator Mulvihill's interest in the age, quality and nature of tankers is well acknowledged by me. Indeed, I have responded to him before. I share his views. But I must say that the age of a vessel is not necessarily a mark of whether it is good or bad. What is important is how well a vessel has been maintained, how well it has been managed and the training of the crew. There are rigid inspection rules in Australia. We would be second to none in wanting to prevent any substandard vessels from coming to Australia. Of course, there will always be dangers in a very real world.

Senator Mulvihill asked me what might happen if an incident were to occur off Australia. I think he mentioned Torres Strait in particular. I am advised that in the case of a vessel creating an incident off Australia, if the flag state of the vessel is party to the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage, action can be taken in the country which is a signatory to that Convention. If the vessel is party to this Convention Australia can take an action within--

TALK.START.PARA: —They wouldn't have to go to Hong Kong.

—No, they would go to the country of the offending vessel if that country were a signatory. In general terms, let me say that wherever it is possible, whether in our very latest attempts to make the platforms in Bass Strait more secure against not only their own spills but also disasters from shipping or otherwise, or in the protection of the Barrier Reef, this Government aims to set the highest possible standards. As new technologies emerge, so we will adapt to them. I acknowledge the work that has been done over the years by committees of both Houses of this Parliament. Senator Cavanagh
1. Question (p. 761 Hansard)
My main concern is who decides the criteria for redundancy? I think the procedures for redeployment or compulsory retirement need explaining.

2. Answer. The procedures for redeployment and compulsory retirement are provided for in the principal Act, in the regulations made under the Act which deal with the processing of appeals, in the administrative procedures which the Board will notify, and in Determination 509 of 1977. (Appeals are referred to in detail later in response to Senators Button and Harradine).
3. Broadly stated the CE (RR) Act
is about the economic and efficient use of staff in Commonwealth employment

provides arrangements for voluntary retirement from age 55 and for the declaration, redeployment and compulsory retirement of staff who can no longer be used by departments because they are surplus, medically unfit, inefficient or incompetent.
requires the Public Service Board to notify administrative procedures for each of those arrangements.

requires Permanent Heads to declare staff for redeployment followed by the Public Service Board either redeploying or certifying that redeployment is not practicable. If redeployment is not practicable, the Permanent Head retires the officer.
creates an independent Commonwealth Employees Redeployment and Retirement Appeals Tribunal to hear appeals against actions made under the Act.

4. Determination 509 of 1977 provides additional arrangements for handling surplus staff situations only. It provides for consultations with unions (the range of these consultations being specified in the administrative procedures). It provides for maximum efforts towards redeployment with notice to permanent officers of 6 or 12 months (depending on age and length of service) income maintenance of 6 or 12 months for temporary employees transferred to a lower level or terminated, and a further one month's notice on full pay before a permanent officer can be transferred to a lower level or terminated.

5. I would mention particularly the administrative procedure made by the Board as these are binding on Permanent Heads. The procedures in relation to redundancy situations, medical situations and situations where staff are inefficient or incompetent have been drafted and circulated to Peak union Councils. They will be discussed with them shortly.
6. In relation to redundancy situations, the procedures specify that a redundancy situation can occur because
(i) the functions of the department are altered as a result of changes to the Administrative Arrangements order
(ii) a function or activity of a department, as changed or altered or the priority accorded to the function or activity changes
(iii) a review of the Department indicates that there may be more staff than is necessary for efficient operation
(iv) the workload of, or staffing provision of the department changes significantly
(v) staff decline to transfer with their function to another locality or
(vi) an unattached officer on return to duty cannot be permanently placed within a reasonable time.

7. The administrative procedures require the Board to give the relevant staff organisations advice and information about the redundancy situation and to arrange discussions. Such discussions would cover the Boards views about the change in the Department which has resulted in an actual or potential excess staff situation, and the criteria which will be used in identifying which staff should be declared eligible for redeployment-Usually the criteria used is relative efficiency. The discussions with staff organisations can also cover measures to avoid the need for declaration, including
retention or modification of existing systems of work in department
suspension of the filling of vacant positions
restrictions on overtime
reviewing the extent of outside contracting, and
use of natural wastage.

8. In short, staff organisations are advised of all actual or potential redundancy situations and there is the opportunity for meaningful consultations between the Board, the Department and the staff organisation about the effect of the redundancy situation and about the criteria which will be applied to identify the staff members who are surplus.

9. Question-The amending Bill effectively removes the Arbitrator's ability to settle disputes arising in the redeployment and retirement area. In the absence of the Arbitrator, what redress does an employee have, especially at the point of termination, against action taken against him?

10. Answer-The CERR Act establishes under s.16 an independent 3-man Commonwealth Employees Redeployment and Retirement Appeals Tribunal comprising a Chairman appointed by the Governor General, a person nominated to represent the employing Department, and a person nominated to represent the employees.
11. S.15 of the act provides that an employee may appeal to the Tribunal against:
(i) a declaration that he is eligible for redeployment that is his services can no longer be reasonably used at his current level;
(ii) any redeployment action taken in respect of the employee;
(iii) a certificate by the PSB (a) that it has not been practical to redeploy the employee, or (b) that by virtue of the employees physical or mental incapacity he should be retired; and
the Tribunal hears and determines the appeal.
(i) In the case of a redeployment declaration the Tribunal may confirm or revoke the declaration, or revoke the declaration and declare another employee

(ii) In the case of redeployment action, the Tribunal may confirm the redeployment action, or set aside the action and remit the matter to the Board. Where the Tribunal sets aside redeployment action, the Act requires that the Board restore the pre-existing situation of the employee. Any subsequent redeployment action by the Board is subject to appeal.
(iii) In the case of a certificate, the Tribunal may confirm or revoke the certificate.
12. Very considerable redress is therefore available to the employee, unless and until-
(i) a certificate referred to in 3 (ii) above has been issued; and
(ii) any appeal against the certificate has been heard and the issue of the certificate has been confirmed.
It is impossible therefore for an employee to be retired against his wishes without him having the opportunity to have his case heard by the independent tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only conceptual difficulty I have with the answer is that if one looks at paragraph No. 6 in relation to Senator Cavanagh's question, the procedures of the Act relating to a redundancy situation, as it is called, are set out. 13. Question 1 (Hansard, page 761)

14. Answer-Yes:-there is redress to the independent tribunal as in paragraphs* above in response to Senator Button.
15. Questions (Hansard, page 761)
'Section 16 of Determination No. 509 provides a right of appeal procedure. It sets up a committee which is the right of appeal committee. Sub-section (3) of section 16 states:
The Committee shall report its findings to the Public Service Board with a recommendation for action appropriate to the case.
They are recommendations. Under what obligation is the Public Service Board to accept these recommendations?'

16. Answer-Clause 16 of the Determination relates only to an appeal against an administrative decision taken in relation to an employee's eligibility for benefits under the determination, or to the amount of such benefits. That is the only right of appeal established by the Determination and, not-withstanding the CERR Act, remains unaltered. The Determination does not oblige the Board to accept the Committee's recommendation.
17. By contrast, the CE(RR) Act has established the very comprehensive avenues of appeal described earlier. The Act has added very considerably to an employees right of independent redress.

18. At page 751 of Hansard Senator Harradine states that 'nobody else but the PSB has any effective final say over whether or not redeployment is feasible'. In reaching this conclusion, he is considering only Determination 509 of 1977 and is disregarding the appeal provisions of the CERR Act itself. Under the CERR Act the actions of the PSB to redeploy and retire are subject to appeal.
The PSB is not the final arbitrator.

19. There is only one area within the appeal mechanism in which the Tribunal itself is not the final arbitrator irrespective of the views of the Board. That is where action is taken to redeploy an employee, such as moving him to another Department at a lower salary. The employee may appeal to the Tribunal which must if it disagrees with the action, 'remit the matter to the Public Service Board to take such other action by way of redeployment of the employee as the Board thinks fit'. The reason for remitting to the Board is that it is the Board, not the Tribunal that has the expertise and knowledge necessary to identify suitable alternative jobs for the employee. It should not be thought however, that the Board on having the matter remitted to it is then free to act in disregard of the Tribunal's decision. Any subsequent action taken by the Board by way of redeployment will itself be subject to appeal to the Tribunal.
20. No redeployment action taken by the Board is capable of implementation unless consented to by the employee or the Tribunal.

21. At page 761 of Hansard, Senator Harradine raised questions in relation to the Government'a attitude to preference for unionists in employment. He sought to imply that the Government's attitude was inconsistent. He contrasts the disallowance of Determination No. 503 of 1980 with the non disallowance of a determination applying similar terms to the Health Insurance Commission and its action to introduce legislative provisions which, in his words 'virtually means that a person working on the waterfront must be a member of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia to be entitled to the provisions of that legislation.'
22. Senator Harradine omits to mention the other relevant part of the comparison.

23. The waterfront is in very large measure an area of private enterprise where union preference is a fact of life and in the circumstances it is not sensible to legislate without recognition of this.

24. Similarly the Health Insurance Commission has also been placed in a sitution where it has to function and compete in the market place. It is part of this process that it accept all that goes with it including what might well be disadvantages.
25. The Government however does not accept that union preference is a matter which should be applicable to the Public Service. In another place the responsible Minister stated that:

'(Union) preference is completely contrary to the objects of the Act and to the principle of merit, a principle which is the cornerstone of the personnel management system of the Service. Preference to union members is quite unacceptable to the Government. Non union members who find themselves surplus to the requirements of the Service would, under the Determination, have lesser rights than union members. Where is the equity and protection of the non union member in this? The Government if it were to accept Determination 503 of 1980 would, in effect, be abandoning those who have exercised their freedom of choice not to belong to a union. This the Government will not countenance.

Apart from the inequity of preference the operation of preference under the Determination would mean that the union member could be retained in employment in preference to a more efficient non union member. That is surely the very antithesis of the efficient management of the Public Service.

The Government is not alone in believing that union preference is incompatible with the merit principle. Our view is shared by Mr Deputy President McKenzie, a member of the Full Bench which considered the unions' applications. In a dissenting opinion on the question of union preference he said 'Notwithstanding the practical impact of granting the claim is likely to be marginal, the use of union membership to choose between employees even in that context is quite inconsistent with the present concepts of the Australian Public Service. I therefore reject the claim'. This Government also rejects the concept of union preference.
The Government is not prepared to see the Public Service become a closed shop.'

I doubt whether another government in the world at any time has offered employers payroll tax concessions to resist the workers' struggle to better their own working conditions. It is almost like paying mercenaries to fight your battle for you. On top of that, the Government intends to spend $2m on a publicity campaign against the 35-hour week. King Canute had to convince his counsellors that he could not hold back the tide. It appears to me that the Government is trying to convince its counsellors that it can hold the tide back. The Government's attitude towards the 35-hour week campaign is paranoic. I heard on the news tonight that this campaign, if successful would jeopardise a $400m ICI Australia Ltd project. A $400m project will be in jeopardy if ICI in any way concedes to the unions to negotiate for the 35-hour week. The workers were threatened with the withdrawal of tariff assistance. Referring to resources development, Senator Chaney stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as resources development intensifies . . . economic growth is consolidated.

We all know the Government's attitude towards the so-called impending resources boom. The way in which it is handling it shows a complete disregard for the workers in Australia. It intends to bring tradesmen into the country. That is despite the 1976 census results. They show that more than 300,000 qualified male tradesmen work in non-tradesmen's jobs in Australia-and the Government intends to bring more tradesmen into the country. The report of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training shows that in Western Australia 39.4 per cent of apprentices do not finish their apprenticeships.

Surely, in the hard, cold world of reality, we must recognise from these facts that people should not be guided by ultruism and nationalistic needs in the selection of a career but rather that they move into the direction of a job which offers them far greater returns, job satisfaction and security. I feel that the call to import skilled workers is an attempt to avoid the issue. It is a short term answer to a long term problem. I think the Government is handling the resources boom very badly indeed.

The Government claims-I think it has underestimated the figure-that 36 per cent of all full time non-managerial employees are currently working less than a 40-hour week. It does not follow, however, that the economy can stand an across-the-board application of a 35-hour week or even a 37 1/2-hour week. There are 300 State and Federal awards providing for a 35-hour week already in existence in this country, and yet the Government does not say that the people who are working a 35-hour week should increase their hours of work to 40. The Government prefers to pick on the process workers and the people who have the soul-destroying jobs and to keep them at the grindstone for 40 hours a week rather than consider a 35-hour week, irrespective of productivity. Referring to the Altona case, the Minister stated:
The Government intervened in this hearing and strongly argued against the settlement. It continues to oppose the productivity bargaining concept in its application to reduce working hours.

Irrespective of productivity, the Government will continue to object to the unions putting up such an argument. How in the name of heaven does the Government expect these workers to put their case? What does the Government expect them to base it on-what the Government thinks is correct or what they think is correct? The Government talks of productivity. The mining industry was responsible for 28 per cent of exports in the nine years ended 1975-76. The value of mineral exports rose during this period from $353m to $2,651m. The work force grew from 54,000 to 76,000, an increase of 40 per cent in a work force which produced an 800 per cent increase in export values. Does the Government expect the unions not to bring this matter into court because the Minister says not to? It is just not good enough for the Government to state that it refuses to accept the productivity argument. What other argument can the unions base their case on if they cannot base it on productivity? Productivity has been defined by the Australian Council of Trade Unions in a number of other cases as value added per employee adjusted for increased prices, which means that it has calculated the value added per employee at constant 1968-69 prices. In the glass industry, in the five years since 1973-74 productivity grew by 21.5 per cent while employment fell by 21.5 per cent, which represents a loss of 1,900 jobs. Cannot the unions bring these sorts of figures into the Court? Cannot they use these figures in their arguments? According to the Government they must not use these figures. During the 1970s productivity in the glass industry increased 70 per cent.

There is a similar situation in the electronics industry. In the five years since 1973-74 employment dropped by over 35 per cent, which represents 12,023 persons, while productivity increased by 35 per cent. Cannot the unions bring those statistics into the court? Cannot they use those statistics in their arguments and negotiations? For the manufacturing industry as a whole, productivity, based on the value added per employee at constant 1968-69 prices, grew by 15 per cent over the five years since 1973-74. Over the same period employment in the manufacturing industry fell by 194,553 or by 14.5 per cent. I think it is ludricrous for the Minister even to entertain let alone put in writing the idea that the Government will continue to oppose productivity bargaining as a concept in union applications for reduced working hours. On page 15 of the statement the Minister said:
If unions believe they have justifiable claims let them come forward and have them tested by arbitration . . .

The Government has just killed the umpire. How can the Government expect anyone to have any confidence in the umpire? No matter what an umpire decides it is pretty obvious that this Government will either try to undermine the umpire or just go against his decision. Therefore, the whole concept of industrial relations has been worsened by the fact that the Government has already killed the umpire. Page 16 of the statement-I think this one is a real lulu-reads:
We are inviting the ACTU to sit down and talk and we will explain in detail the reasons for our opposition to reduced working hours, higher wage demands and the economic consequences of such actions.

I have never heard such a one-eyed, arrogant attitude in all of my life. The Government will bring in the unions and tell them why the Government has adopted this attitude. Quite frankly, 90 per cent of the members on the opposite side of the House would not be where they are but for the early struggles of the trade union movement for representation in the Parliament. The members of the trade union movement are the pioneers in this respect.

For the Government to carry on with its attitude of opposing a reduction in the 40-hour week is really wasting time because there is no way that the Government can stop the reduction. I can assure honourable senators that Australia is not alone in this fight. Internationally there is a move to reduce working hours which parallels the campaign that is currently taking place for a reduction in standard hours in Australia. France, Italy, Germany and other developed economies are experiencing trade union campaigns for a 35-hour week. In Japan workers in the manufacturing industry are already working fewer than 40 hours a week. The ACTU has made it quite clear it does not intend to bring in a 35-hour week in a few days or in a few months. It expects a fair share of increased productivity where industry can afford the 35-hour week, but the Government is determined that the 35-hour week will not come in at all because it is absolutely paranoid in its opposition to the trade union movement. It is intent on causing confrontation in the country instead of taking a more sensible attitude. It should at least allow the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to be free of the bias of the Government and allow the unions to have more confidence in the process of arbitration. But the Government has undermined the confidence of the unions in the arbitration of the campaign for a 35-hour week. This is pretty obvious according to what Mr Dolan has to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it weren't for the working class they wouldn't be here.

—That is right. The tories and the whigs would still be sitting over there. It is only the mimics of the tories and the whigs that are sitting there. It would have been the real thing but for the trade union movement.
—We have been unionists, too.

—If you are unionists all I can say is that you are a disgrace to the union movement. This Government expects a return to the Victorian era with the Frasers, the Thatchers and the Reagans. This Government may as well forget it because there is not way we will turn back to the days of the servant and the master. Those days have gone. The 35-hour week is absolutely inevitable. There is nothing that the Government can do to stop it. It is only a matter of time before it is introduced. The ACTU has taken a reasonable attitude on this issue and it expects the shorter working week to be introduced in those industries which can afford it.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

(b) research into the most economical use of irrigation water.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Agricultural research, including genetic development of salt tolerant crops, is undertaken by a diversity of research institutions throughout Australia. Principal organisations are the State Departments of Agriculture/Primary Industries, the CSIRO and the Universities. Precise and comprehensive information from these and other organisations is not available. In regard to the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry, it is directly involved through the support to individual research projects by the statutory and non-statutory research funds it administers.
Details of such projects relevant to the honourable senator's question, which are currently being supported from these sources, are given immediately below. Allocations this financial year are shown.
Investigation of genetic and physiological aspects of tolerance to salinity (sodium chloride) in lucerne
Evaluation of crop tolerance to salinity from leaf fluorescence properties

I understand that the CSIRO Division of Horticultural Research, as part of its program of crop improvement, is currently engaged in the development of techniques for the selection of more salt tolerant plant types. Crops under study include grapevines; a range of tropical and sub-tropical fruit and nut species such as the avocado; citrus; and the Australian natives, macadamia and quandong. Previous work by the Division with rootstocks has led to the release of salt tolerant rootstocks for sultanas.

I also understand that the CSIRO Division of Plant Industry is developing a salt tolerant lucerne cultivar for use in previously valuable country where increasing salinity has resulted from a rising water table. The same Division is also embarking on an examination of mechanisms which bestow salt tolerance on dryland crops.

(b) As in the case of plant breeding, irrigation research, both of a technical and economic nature, is undertaken by a similar diversity of organisations in Australia and precise and comprehensive information from all sources is not available.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has undertaken a detailed analysis of the economics of irrigation and in February 1980 published its report entitled 'Irrigation Issues for the Eighties: Focusing on Efficiency and Equity in the Management of Agricultural Water Supplies'. Main conclusions of the report are:
the most important issues concerning irrigation in Australia in the 1980's relate to management of established water supplies rather than to development of new supplies.
water quality issues and the formulation of more appropriate pricing and institutional systems will be of increasing importance.
current practices of pricing water below its economic value and restricting exchange between users, do not encourage efficient use of water.
development of more appropriate management systems will require improved information on the benefits and costs of alternative uses.

In conjunction with the New South Wales Department of Agriculture, the CSIRO Division of Plant Industry is developing a comprehensive on-farm computer-based management strategy system for cotton growing which focuses on the use of insecticides, fertilizer and water. The system, known as SIRATAC, has proven highly successful to date in trials on commercial cotton farms and CSIRO is investigating means of making it generally available throughout the industry.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Development Association and Asian Development Fund

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 March, 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has been taken by (a) the United States Administration, (b) the United States Senate, (c) the United States House of Representatives and (d) other countries on the (i) sixth replenishment of the International Development Association and (ii) second replenishment of the Asian Development Fund since the answer provided by the former Minister for Foreign Affairs to my question No. 3030 (see Senate Hansard, 18 September 1980, page 1412).
(2) To what extent have the lending activities of the IDA and ADF been reduced or deferred by failures to contribute to the replenishments since that answer.
(3) To what extent have donor countries (a) made bridging arrangements; or (b) reassessed their contributions since that answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (i) The United States Administration has not as yet obtained legislative authorisation for its participation in the sixth replenishment of the International Development Association (IDA 6). Following reports last month that the new United States Administration was considering cuts in the IDA 6 pledge made by the previous United States Administration, Australia along with a number of other countries made formal representations in Washington urging the United States Administration to maintain its negotiated contributions. It was subsequently confirmed that the United States Administration will request Congressional authorization for the full amount previously pledged to IDA 6. As mentioned in the answer provided to question No. 3030, most other IDA donors agreed to participate in a bridging arrangement by making advance contributions to IDA. This bridging arrangement which became effective in October 1980 involves 17 countries and advance contributions totalling $US1.74 billion. Australia has made available an advance contribution of $67.8m.

(1) (ii) In December 1980 the United States Government paid to the Asian Development Bank the second instalment in the amount of $US111.25m of its contribution to the second replenishment of the Asian Development Fund. Payment of this instalment by the United States released the third tranches of other donors' contributions for loan commitment on 1 January 1981.

(2) (i) The bridging arrangements described above have allowed the lending activities of IDA to continue normally. However, IDA commitment authority is expected to run out early in April 1981 before United States Congress is expected to have taken action to allow IDA 6 to become effective. Accordingly, IDA donors will meet again at the end of March 1981 to consider action designed to allow IDA lending activities to continue unimpeded.

(2) (ii) The second replenishment of the ADF is still on course and the Bank's concessional lending program continues to progress normally. Consequently, the question of bridging arrangements does not arise and donor countries have not reassessed their contributions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What guidelines on conduct apply to officers of the Department of Defence who are involved in making decisions on tenders and contracts awarded by the Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

(2) Yes. The Public Service Board Guidelines, adopted by the Department, and referred to in (1) cover post separation employment as defined in the Bowen Committee Report.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1981 (Hansard, page 85) Senator Rae asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice concerning the south-western Tasmania wilderness area.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following information for answer to the honourable senator's question:

As part of our election policy in 1975 we promised to assist the Tasmanian Government to establish a national park of world significance in south-western Tasmania which would include a substantial wilderness area. In accordance with this commitment the Commonwealth allocated $350,000 towards meeting the cost of a detailed resources survey of the south-west. The survey aims to identify to the Tasmanian Government those attributes of the area, including wilderness values, which might require reservation and management as a national park.

The Tasmanian Government has also been advised of the Commonwealth's undertaking to consider requests for assistance for specific proposals associated with the protection of the region as soon as the survey is completed.

The Government does believe, however, that land management and land use decisions are primarily the responsibility of State governments and decisions on the development of the south-west are therefore the responsibility of the Tasmanian Government.
The Tasmanian Premier and the Prime Minister have a clear understanding that decisions on power development in Tasmania are a matter for the Tasmanian Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 February (Hansard, page 149) Senator Evans asked me, without notice, whether a convention or a practice has emerged over the last two decades whereby Governors-General are invariably Australian citizens and whether the Government intends to continue honouring this convention.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
